         a.   At point of purchase there shall be displayed a clearly visible
sign indicating the illegality of acting as a straw buyer for another person.
      4.   Commission:
         a.   A commission structure incentive program shall not be used in the
sale of firearms. (Ord. 16-04, 2-8-2016)
4-11-5: INTERGOVERNMENTAL AGREEMENT:
The Village and Cook County Sheriff will enter into an Intergovernmental
Agreement (IGA) specifying that enforcement of this chapter is by the Village
of Hodgkins, in collaboration with the Cook County Sheriff. Only the Village of
Hodgkins may enforce the provisions of this chapter. (Ord. 16-04, 2-8-2016)
4-11-6: PENALTIES:
If there are multiple (more than 2) willful violations of any or all of the
items specified within a consecutive twelve (12) month period the Village
President may suspend or fine the business license of the gun shop following a
hearing as provided by this Code. After the first violation, there may be an
additional, random inspection made during that calendar year in addition to the
other inspections as set forth in this chapter. The President may consult with
the Cook County Sheriff and any other appropriate law enforcement authorities
prior to imposing any penalty. The holder of the business license is entitled
to service of process of the charges, and to a hearing not more than five (5)
days from service of the charges. (Ord. 16-04, 2-8-2016)
CHAPTER 12
MOBILE FOOD UNITS
SECTION:
4-12-1: Definition
4-12-2: License Procedures, Fees And Regulations
4-12-3: General Operation Prohibited
4-12-4: Certificate Of Inspection
4-12-5: Duties
4-12-1: DEFINITION:
MOBILE FOOD UNIT: Any food service establishment or vehicle from which food is
served without a fixed location and which is capable of being readily moved
from location to location. This term does not include a food service
establishment or vehicle which serves only ice cream products. (Ord. 21-05, 5-
20-2021)
4-12-2: LICENSE PROCEDURES, FEES AND REGULATIONS:
The license procedures and fees for mobile food units shall be as required in
Chapter 1 and thereafter of this title. Further, the regulations contained in
this article shall be in addition to and shall not supersede, the regulations
contained in said Chapter 1 and thereafter of this title. (Ord. 21-05, 5-20-
2021)
4-12-3: GENERAL OPERATION PROHIBITED:
It shall be unlawful to sell or otherwise distribute food from a mobile food
unit on the public streets and way of the Village. The distribution of food by
mobile units shall be limited to off-street premises, such as construction
sites, industrial or other commercial areas. Written permission from the owner
or person in charge of such premises shall be obtained prior to the
distribution of food from a mobile food unit. (Ord. 21-05, 5-20-2021)
4-12-4: CERTIFICATE OF INSPECTION:
All mobile food units are required to obtain and display a current certificate
of inspection from the Cook County Department of Public Health. (Ord. 21-05, 5-
20-2021)
4-12-5: DUTIES:
It shall be the duty of the Code Enforcement Officer to also inspect all mobile
food units. The method and frequency of such inspections shall be as deemed
necessary by the Code Enforcement Officer. (Ord. 21-05, 5-20-2021)
TITLE 5
PUBLIC HEALTH AND SAFETY
CHAPTER 1
HEALTH AND SAFETY ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT
SECTION:
5-1-1: Health Officer
5-1-2: Vital Statistics Records
5-1-3: Fire Protection
5-1-4: Violations; Penalties
5-1-1: HEALTH OFFICER:
   A.   Appointment; Qualifications: The village president, with the advice and
consent of the board of trustees, shall appoint a health officer who shall be a
licensed healthcare professional and who shall serve at the pleasure of the
village president. (Ord. 97-6, 3-10-1997)
   B.   Conservator Of The Peace: The health officer is hereby appointed a
conservator of the peace of the village and shall have the powers as such and
as set forth in state law, and is hereby authorized to enforce all the
provisions of this code and any other ordinances of the village pertaining to
health. (1985 Code § 1-8-6; amd. 2016 Code)
   C.   Duties; Assistance From Police Officers:
      1.   It shall be the duty of the health officer:
         a.   To enforce and observe all rules, regulations and orders of the
Illinois department of public health and all state laws pertaining to the
preservation of the health of the people within the village.
         b.   To execute and enforce all ordinances of the village relating to
nuisances and public health and sanitation.
         c.   To investigate the existence of any contagious or infectious
disease within the village and to report the same promptly to the village board
and to the department of health of the state of Illinois, and to act without
delay in carrying out such measures for arresting the progress of the same as
either or both of said bodies shall adopt.
         d.   To make all necessary sanitary and health investigations and
inspections within the village.
      2.   The village police officers shall assist the health officer in the
performance of his duties when called upon by said health officer or by the
village president or board of trustees or any member thereof.
   D.   Deputy Health Officer: To assist the health officer or in the absence
of one or failure to appoint, a deputy health officer may be appointed in like
manner, who shall be versed in medical care, and who shall perform similar
duties to those prescribed for the health officer.
   E.   Compensation: The health officer and deputy health officer shall
receive, as compensation for their services, amounts to be fixed by the village
board from time to time. If the health officer or deputy health officer is a
village trustee, there shall be no additional compensation for this office.
(1985 Code § 4-1-1; amd. 2016 Code)
5-1-2: VITAL STATISTICS RECORDS:
   A.   Registrar Of Vital Statistics: The village clerk shall be the local
registrar for the purpose of recording vital statistics, and he shall be
governed by 410 Illinois Compiled Statutes, public health. Said local registrar
shall cooperate with the Cook County department of public health and shall be
responsible for the issuance of permits for the burial or removal of bodies.
   B.   Deputy Registrar: The local registrar shall appoint a deputy to be
known as the deputy local registrar who shall act in case of the local
registrar's absence, illness or disability.
   C.   Birth Reports: It shall be the duty of every physician or midwife who
attends the birth of a child, to report the same to the local registrar within
thirty (30) days from the date of such birth. Such reports shall be made in
writing on blank forms to be furnished by the registrar and shall give the name
and date of birth of such child and such other information as the registrar
shall require. (1985 Code § 4-1-2; amd. 2016 Code)
5-1-3: FIRE PROTECTION:
The prevention of fires and firefighting are under the jurisdiction of the
Pleasant View fire protection district, except as may be modified herein. (1985
Code § 4-1-3)
5-1-4: VIOLATIONS; PENALTIES:
   A.   Penalty; Citation:
      1.   Any person who violates any provision of this title, unless a
different penalty is provided under another section of this title, shall be
subject to the penalty provisions and citation procedures set out in section 1-
4-4 of this code.
      2.   The health officer or deputy health officer is hereby authorized to
follow the citation procedures, including the fines therein enumerated, for any
violation of any provision of this code or other ordinances heretofore enacted
or hereafter enacted, the violation of which may affect the public health of
the village.
   B.   Revocation Of License: The village president may, upon the
certification of a health officer that a business has violated the provisions
of this title and that the health of the public is being endangered by the
maintenance or conduct of said business, revoke any license given to said
business under any provisions of this code or any other ordinances of the
village. The revocation procedures set forth in section
4-1-9 of this code shall be applicable herein, including notice procedures.
   C.   Closing Premises: The health officer or deputy health officer may close
any premises when, in his judgment, the public health and safety are
jeopardized. The situation of fact as determined by him is hereby declared to
be a public nuisance, and the premises shall remain closed until the public
health hazard is removed or corrected and the nuisance abated. To effect these
purposes, he may give notices to correct the same within a definite period of
time before closing the premises. In the event the village corrects the
violation, the cost of the same shall be reimbursed to the village by the
owner, lessor, lessee, occupant or one in possession of the premises, and the
village shall have a lien as provided for in state law. (1985 Code § 4-1-4)
CHAPTER 2
GENERAL HEALTH AND SAFETY PROVISIONS
SECTION:
5-2-1: Open Burning
5-2-1-1: Recreational Burning And Cooking Outdoors
5-2-2: Air Pollution Control
5-2-3: Weeds, Garbage And Debris
5-2-4: Junk Storage And Accumulation
5-2-1: OPEN BURNING:
   A.   No person shall burn any standing hay or grass, nor set fire to nor
burn any leaves or other combustible material in any park or public way or
grounds.
   B.   No person shall burn leaves or other combustible material, or build any
bonfire upon any brick, asphalt or block pavement in any street or alley nor in
or upon any street or alley.
   C.   No person shall burn or set fire to any combustible material in any
open fire on public or private property.
   D.   No garbage, manure, leaves, refuse, waste, rubbish, paper, wood or
combustible material shall be burned in the open or in any container. The
burning of combustible material other than garbage, manure and materials which
produce offensive odors is permissible in a commercial incinerator designed for
that purpose, and only in accordance with federal and state EPA rules and
regulations. (1985 Code § 4-2-1)
5-2-1-1: RECREATIONAL BURNING AND COOKING OUTDOORS:
   A.   Definitions: When used in this section, the following terms shall have
the following meanings:
   DENSE SMOKE: Smoke with a degree of density of number 3 on the Ringelmann
smoke chart, or greater, for more than six (6) minutes in any one hour, whether
such period of time is consecutive or not.
   FIRE RING: A construction or device used to contain fires and prevent them
from spreading into a wildfire.
   GARBAGE: Refuse resulting from the handling, processing, preparation,
cooking, and consumption of food or food products.
   OPEN BURNING: The combustion of any matter in the open or in an open dump.
   OUTDOOR FIREPLACE: A device designed to be used for recreational burning
which is portable or permanently affixed to the ground and is located outside
of a structure or building.
   RECREATIONAL BURNING: Fires for the express purpose of cooking food for
human consumption contained inside grills, charcoal burners, or the like; fires
within a dry stacked stone, masonry, or metal fire pit/ring, or commercially
manufactured portable fireplaces.
   REFUSE: Any discarded matter including, but not limited to, garbage,
sweepings, landscape waste, paper, cardboard, tin cans, ashes, bottles and/or
similar matter.
   SEASONED LOGS: Logs that are aged or dried.
   YARD WASTE: Accumulations of grass or shrubbery cuttings, leaves, tree
limbs, and other materials generated as the result of lawn care.
   B.   Conditions Of Burning: Recreational burning shall be permitted only
under the following conditions:
      1.   An outdoor fireplace or fire ring shall be placed at a safe and
reasonable distance from any building, structure, or vehicle, or from any
container or other source of flammable liquids or vapors and shall not be
placed on any combustible surface.
      2.   An outdoor fireplace or fire ring shall only be fueled by seasoned
logs or its equal.
      3.   A water source or other provisions for extinguishing the fire shall
be immediately accessible and attended constantly by a person eighteen (18)
years of age or older at all times when the outdoor fireplace or fire ring is
in use.
      4.   The burning of any refuse, yard waste or any other combustible
material in an outdoor fireplace or fire ring is prohibited.
      5.   An outdoor or portable fireplace shall not be used in such a manner
as to emit dense smoke, or objectionable smoke/odors, or when atmospheric
conditions or other circumstances make such fires hazardous.
   C.   Exemptions: Charcoal grills, burners or like devices used solely for
the cooking of food are allowed and are not subject to the provisions contained
in subsection B of this section. (Ord. 13-11, 9-9-2013)
5-2-2: AIR POLLUTION CONTROL:
   A.   Contaminant Matter: The escape or emission into the open air of
noxious, nauseous or offensive contaminant matter, or any one or more of them,
is hereby declared to be unlawful and a nuisance. No person shall cause or
allow the escape or emission into the open air of such noxious, nauseous or
offensive contaminant matter.
   B.   Noxious Gases; Nauseous Gases, Odors And Offensive Smells: The escape
or emission into the open air of noxious gases or nauseous gases or nauseous
odors or offensive smells, or any one or more of them, is hereby declared to be
a nuisance. No person shall cause or allow the escape or emission into the open
air of any of such noxious gases, nauseous gases, nauseous odors or offensive
smells.
   C.   Smoke Emissions: It shall be unlawful for any person to suffer or allow
to emit or discharge smoke or contaminant matter into the atmosphere, the
appearance, density or shade of which is number 3 or darker on the Ringelmann
chart as published and described in the U.S. bureau of mines "Information
Circular No. 8333", which chart shall be the standard for estimating the light
obscurity and determining the appearance, density or shade of smoke. (1985 Code
§ 4-2-2; amd. 2016 Code)
   D.   Illinois Smoke Free Air Act Adopted: The Illinois smoke free air act,
410 Illinois Compiled Statutes 82/1 et seq., is hereby adopted by reference as
if fully set out at length herein. Copies of the act are on file in the office
of the village clerk for public use and inspection. (2016 Code)
5-2-3: WEEDS, GARBAGE AND DEBRIS:
   A.   It shall be unlawful for any owner, lessee or occupant, or any agent,
servant, representative or employee of such owner, lessee or occupant, having
control of any lot or part of a lot to: (1985 Code § 4-2-3)
      1.   Weeds:
         a.   Within two hundred feet (200') of any building occupied as a
private residence or place of business, allow or maintain on any such lot or
part thereof any growth of weeds to a height in excess of ten inches (10").
(Ord. 93-13, 7-12-1993)
         b.   Allow the growth of noxious weeds, as defined in state law, to
any height.
      2.   Garbage And Debris: Allow garbage and debris to remain thereon or
allow the accumulation of garbage or debris in any public alley, sidewalk,
parkway or street contiguous thereto. (1985 Code § 4-2-3)
      3.   Abandoned, Wrecked Vehicles: Allow an abandoned, wrecked or
partially wrecked motor vehicle to remain thereon, except on lots duly licensed
as motor vehicle repair shops.
      4.   Diseased Dutch Elm Trees: Allow a diseased Dutch elm tree to remain
on the premises.
   B.   It shall be the duty of every owner to cut such weeds and to remove the
garbage, debris and abandoned, wrecked or partially wrecked vehicles at his own
expense. In the event said owner refuses or neglects to cut said weeds or
remove the garbage, debris and vehicles as herein provided, the village may
provide for the cutting or removal of the same and collect the reasonable costs
thereof from the owner after service of a notice on the person who refuses or
neglects to do so. The notice of the time to remove or correct shall depend on
the hazard to the health or danger to the public but in no case shall exceed
five (5) days. The village shall file a lien upon the real estate affected
which shall include the cost, plus interest at five percent (5%) per annum from
the date said cost was incurred, together with the cost of recording. The lien
may be enforced by proceeding to foreclose as in the case of mortgages or
mechanics' liens. Suit to foreclose this lien shall be commenced within two (2)
years after date of the filing of the lien. (1985 Code § 4-2-3; amd. 2016 Code)
5-2-4: JUNK STORAGE AND ACCUMULATION:
   A.   It shall be unlawful for any person to store or keep any old articles
or materials which may be classified as junk adjacent to or in close proximity
to any school, church, public park, public grounds, business building or
residence without first providing proper and tight buildings for the storage of
the same. The storing or accumulating of unsightly material of any kind
including, but not limited to, garbage, metals, junk of every kind and
character, nonfunctioning motor vehicles and trash of every kind and nature on
any property or lot within the village is hereby prohibited. (1985 Code § 4-2-
4)
   B.   It shall be unlawful for any owner, his manager or agent, or the
lessor, lessee or occupant of any premises to discard, permit or keep on the
premises any discarded article, vehicle, or abandoned article or vehicle, or
material of any kind or description. Any motor vehicle which remains on the
premises, other than a duly licensed garage, terminal or automobile sales
agency, for more than five (5) days without a license, or without being moved,
shall be presumed to be discarded and abandoned and summarily removed or towed
away at the expense of the owner of the vehicle, his manager or agent, or the
lessor or lessee, or occupant of the premises. (1985 Code § 4-2-4; amd. 2016
Code)
   C.   The storing or accumulation of any of the aforesaid which may or can
become breeding grounds or harborage for or attraction to insects, rodents, or
other possible disease carrying animals on any property or lot within the
village is prohibited. In the extermination of rats, charging the cost thereof
to the owner, occupant or person interested in the premises shall be controlled
by state law. (1985 Code § 4-2-4)
CHAPTER 3
NUISANCES
SECTION:
5-3-1: Nuisances Prohibited
5-3-2: Nuisances Enumerated
5-3-3: Abatement
5-3-4: Penalties
5-3-1: NUISANCES PROHIBITED:
It shall be unlawful to commit any offense which is a nuisance according to the
common law of the land, or made such by any provision of this code or other
village ordinances, or by the statutes of the state. (1985 Code § 4-3-1)
5-3-2: NUISANCES ENUMERATED:
It is hereby declared to be a nuisance for any person, within the limits of the
village, to do any of the following:
   A.   Common Law Nuisances: Commit any offense which is a nuisance according
to the common law of the land, or made such by the statutes of the state. (1985
Code § 4-3-2)
   B.   Nuisances Enumerated In State Law: All those nuisances described in 720
Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/47-5, which section is herein incorporated by
reference and made a part hereof. (1985 Code § 4-3-2; amd. 2016 Code)
   C.   Violation Of Village Regulations: Violate any provision of the building
code, fire code or zoning regulations or allow any premises to be in a
condition declared by the village president to be a nuisance. (1985 Code § 4-3-
2)
   D.   Building Operations: To conduct any building operations between the
hours of ten o'clock (10:00) P.M. and seven o'clock (7:00) A.M.; or to operate
any steam shovels, pneumatic hammers, steam or electric hoists or other
apparatus, the use of which is attended with loud or unusual noise, in any
block in which more than half of the buildings on either side of the street are
used exclusively for residence purposes.
   E.   Animal Carcasses, Slops, Etc.:
      1.   Cause or suffer the carcass of any animal or vegetable matter,
slops, swill, mud, garbage, filth, stable drippings, offal or other similar
substance of any kind to be collected or deposited or to remain in any place in
the village to the prejudice of others. (1985 Code § 4-3-2; amd. 2016 Code)
      2.   Permit any slops, swill, garbage, stable drippings, offal, filth,
refuse, animal or vegetable matter, which is liable to become putrid or
offensive or injurious to health, to remain on any premises used or occupied by
said person, for a longer period than twelve (12) hours at a time.
   F.   Food Vendors Using Containers: The custom among merchants dealing in
ice cream, ices, soda waters and other soft drinks of delivering at the curb,
in the street or upon the sidewalks or roadways their merchandise in paper
cups, cartons, plates or other containers has become a nuisance and a menace to
pedestrians and persons traveling on the roadway by reason of the depositing of
such cups, cartons, plates or other containers on the sidewalks and streets,
and the delivery of such commodities in containers upon the public streets
anywhere is hereby declared to be a nuisance and a menace.
   G.   Contaminating Drinking Water: Corrupt or render unwholesome or impure
the water of any drinking hydrant, spring, stream, pond or lake, to the injury
and prejudice of others. (1985 Code § 4-3-2)
   H.   Premises In Filthy Condition: Keep or suffer to be kept in a foul,
offensive, nauseous or filthy condition, any chicken coop, cow house, stable,
cellar, vault, drain, privy, sewer or sink upon any premises belonging to or
occupied by said person, or any railroad car, building, mobile home unit, yard,
grounds and premises belonging to or occupied by said person. (1985 Code § 4-3-
2; amd. 2016 Code)
   I.   Litter: Throw or drop any cup, plate or container upon a sidewalk,
crosswalk, roadway or any part of any public street.
   J.   Unwholesome Business:
      1.   Generally: To establish, maintain and carry on any offensive or
unwholesome business within the limits of the village or within one mile of the
limits thereof.
      2.   Packinghouses, Etc.: Locate and carry on any packinghouses,
renderies, tallow chandleries, glue and bone factories, soap factories and
tanneries within the limits of the village and within the distance of one mile
outside the village limits.
      3.   Building Used For Offensive Business: Erect, continue or use any
building or other place for the exercise of any trade, employment or
manufacture which, by occasion of noxious exhalations, offensive smells or
otherwise, is offensive or dangerous to the health of individuals or of the
public.
   K.   Night Soil; Dead Animals: Deposit any night soil, dead animal or other
filthy, offensive or noisome substance upon any lot, street, alley, highway,
park or other place.
   L.   Noise: For any person owning or in possession, charge or control of any
building or premises to use the same, or permit the use of the same, or rent
the same to be used for any business or employment, or for any purpose of
pleasure or recreation, if such use shall, from its noise or boisterous nature,
disturb or destroy the peace of the neighborhood in which such building or
premises is situated, or be dangerous or detrimental to health.
   M.   Obstructing Public Ways: Obstruct or encroach upon public highways,
private ways, streets, alleys and commons.
   N.   Obstructing Watercourses; Stagnant Water:
      1.   Obstruct any watercourse, ravine or gutter so as to cause water to
stagnate therein, or to permit foul or stagnant water to stand upon any
premises to the prejudice of others.
      2.   Allow water to accumulate and remain in a pond or ponds either
wholly or partly within the limits of any private property for a period of more
than ten (10) consecutive days. For the purpose of this subsection, the term
"pond" shall be considered to mean any exposed surface of water not less than
one hundred (100) square feet in area which has accumulated either by natural
or artificial means in any depression or connected series of depressions of
excavation, whether existing naturally or created artificially.
   O.   Offensive Animal Pens: Own, use or keep any yard, pen, place, railroad
car or premises, in or upon which cattle or other animals shall be confined or
kept, so as to be offensive to those residing in the vicinity, or to an
annoyance to others.
   P.   Offensive Smells: To negligently conduct any business or use any
premises as to create such an offensive smell as may taint the air and render
it unwholesome or disagreeable in the neighborhood.
   Q.   Privies: Erect or maintain any privy within the village.
   R.   Slaughtering Animals: Slaughter or kill any cattle, hogs or sheep, or
keep, maintain or use in the village any house or place in which the business
of slaughtering any of said animals may be carried on.
   S.   Smoke Emissions: Allow or permit any dense smoke to come or be emitted
from any fire, chimney, engine, oil burner or other agency within the limits of
the village. Said nuisance may be summarily abated by the village president or
health officer, or by anyone whom they or either of them may authorize for such
purpose. Such abatement may be in addition to the fine provided for violation
of this chapter.
   T.   Accumulation Of Grass, Leaves And Combustibles: Cause or suffer grass,
leaves, underbrush or other combustible matter to be collected, deposited or
remain on the premises in such quantities and in such condition as to
materially increase the danger to property of others from forest or other
fires.
   U.   Throwing Offal In Watercourse: Throw or deposit, or cause to be thrown
or deposited, any offal or other offensive matter, or the carcass of any animal
in any watercourse, pond, spring or well within the limits of the village.
   V.   Poplar And Cottonwood Trees: Permit the growth upon any premises of any
poplar or cottonwood trees defined as follows:
A "poplar tree" is any of a genus of slender, quick growing salicaceous trees
also known as Populus. A "cottonwood tree" is a tree of the poplar group with a
cottony comma investing the seeds, also known as Populus balsamifera.
   W.   Unsightly Yards: Permit or maintain an unsightly yard or premises where
there is an accumulation or deposit of any vehicles, equipment, material of any
nature, waste or earth; or maintain an unsightly yard or area where junk,
wrecked or disabled automobiles, trucks, equipment or other such matter is
allowed to accumulate. (1985 Code § 4-3-2)
5-3-3: ABATEMENT:
Whenever any nuisance exists or shall be found on any premises within the
village, whether or not such nuisance is one specifically recognized by statute
or by this code, the village president is hereby authorized, in his discretion,
to cause it to be summarily abated in such manner as he may direct, and at the
expense of the party permitting or maintaining the nuisance. Statement of the
nuisance and abatement required shall be directed in writing by the village
president to the last known business or residence of the person owning or
maintaining the source of the nuisance. The abatement must take place within
five (5) days of notice or earlier in the event an emergency exists, when such
nuisance is an imminent threat to the health, safety or welfare of the
citizenry. The notice provided herein may be waived by the village president
wherein the nuisance must be abated immediately either by the person charged or
by the village. If the village shall perform the abatement either under the
emergency manner stated herein or if the person charged fails to abate within
the five (5) day period, the village shall be reimbursed for all its costs
either by the person charged with the nuisance or the owner of the property or
device where the nuisance emanated. (1985 Code § 4-3-3; amd. 2016 Code)
5-3-4: PENALTIES:
Any person who violates any provision of this chapter shall be fined not less
than twenty five dollars ($25.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00),
and if the offender shall fail to abate the nuisance, then, and in such case,
any offender shall be held to a penalty of not less than seventy five dollars
($75.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each and every
day the nuisance shall remain in existence after notice to abate same has been
given. (1985 Code § 4-3-4; amd. 2016 Code)
CHAPTER 4
GARBAGE AND REFUSE
SECTION:
5-4-1: Definitions
5-4-2: Collection And Removal Requirements
5-4-3: Containers
5-4-4: Permit To Dump Refuse
5-4-5: Prohibited Accumulations And Disposal
5-4-6: Building Construction
5-4-7: Offensive, Unwholesome Materials
5-4-8: Sanitary Landfills Prohibited
5-4-9: Nuisance Declared; Abatement And Enforcement
5-4-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this chapter, the following words and terms shall be
understood as having the following meanings:
   ASHES: All ashes of paper, wood, coal and coke; and the residue resulting
from the combustion of any material or substance, soot, cinders, slag or
charcoal.
   BUSINESS: Any retail or wholesale establishment, industry, factory or
establishment of any kind not specifically defined herein.
   GARBAGE: Refuse; organic matter; fish, animal and vegetable wastes or fats;
and rejected or waste household food, offal, swill or carrion.
   LIVING UNIT: An apartment used as a single housekeeping unit for one family,
or used for living, sleeping, cooking and eating, by one or more persons. The
term includes a trailer or mobile home.
   MANURE: The excrement of all domestic animals and fowl; stable bedding; and
all hay, straw, shavings, grass and weeds, or leaves which have been used for
stable or fowl house bedding.
   MULTIPLE DWELLING: A building or part of a building designed, intended or
used as an apartment house, apartment hotel, tenement house or other use in
which there is more than one dwelling.
   OCCUPATIONAL UNIT: A building or part of a building designed, intended or
used for any purpose other than a single dwelling or multiple dwelling.
   OWNER: Any person, partnership, corporation, syndicate, trustee or person
paying the last year's general real estate taxes, who has ownership or apparent
ownership of record. In cases of land trust, the owners shall be the
beneficiaries or any such person who shall have an interest therein and, as
such, it shall be the duty of such trustee to disclose the beneficiaries and
owners as provided in state law.
   REFUSE: All garbage; ashes; and all other rejected matter, rubbish, dust and
miscellaneous waste, but not including manure or discarded construction or
building material.
   SINGLE DWELLING: A building designed as, or intended for, or used as a
residence for a single family, or for a group of persons other than a single
family, which group does not exceed five (5) in number.
   TRAILER OR MOBILE HOME: Any vehicle or similar portable structure used or so
constructed as to permit its being used as a conveyance upon the public streets
or highways and designed to permit the occupancy thereof as a dwelling place
for one or more persons; provided, that any such structure resting in whole on
a permanent foundation with wheels, tongue and hitch permanently removed, shall
be construed as a "trailer" or "mobile home". (1985 Code § 4-4-1)
5-4-2: COLLECTION AND REMOVAL REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Dwellings And Businesses:
      1.   It shall be the duty of the owner, his manager or agent, or the
lessor, lessee or occupant of every single and multiple dwelling, occupational
or living unit, or business with less than ninety six (96) gallons of refuse,
to cause to be removed, at his own cost and expense, at least once each week,
all refuse produced therein; except, that in trailers or mobile homes, refuse
containers shall be emptied at least every three (3) days.
      2.   In the case of a business which produces more than ninety six (96)
gallons of refuse per week, it shall be the duty of the occupant to cause to be
removed, at his own expense and cost, at least twice each week, all refuse
produced therein.
   B.   Food Establishments: Every person owning or controlling any hotel,
restaurant, cafe or retail food establishment shall cause all garbage to be
placed in sanitary refuse containers, and shall cause all substances deposited
in such containers to be removed daily from his premises and to be disposed of.
Such person shall cause the removal and disposition of such substances at his
own expense and in accordance with the provisions of this code and the rules or
regulations of the building inspector relating to the disposition and removal
of such substances.
   C.   Removal By Collector Or Scavenger 1 : It shall be unlawful for any
person other than a village refuse collector or a private scavenger licensed by
the village to remove, displace, uncover or otherwise disturb any refuse
container or the contents thereof when placed on location as provided in
subsection
5-4-3B of this chapter.
   D.   Removal Before Vacation Of Premises: It shall be the duty of every
person occupying or controlling any lot, building or structure, or any portion
thereof, to remove or cause to be removed therefrom, before vacating the same,
all garbage, ashes, miscellaneous waste and manure. (1985 Code § 4-4-2)
 
Notes
1 1. See article A of this chapter.
5-4-3: CONTAINERS:
   A.   Containers Required:
      1.   Single Dwellings: To deposit or remove refuse, the occupant of every
single dwelling shall provide and maintain in good condition and repair not
less than two (2) standard refuse containers.
      2.   Multiple Dwellings:
         a.   It shall be the duty of the owner, lessee, lessor or occupant,
his manager or agent, of every multiple dwelling to provide and maintain, in
good condition and repair, standard refuse containers whose combined capacity
shall be not less than fifteen (15) gallons for each living unit.
         b.   The owner, his manager or agent, or lessee or lessor of every
multiple dwelling, where the refuse is removed at the owner's expense, shall
provide at least two (2) standard refuse containers for each floor and not less
than two (2) standard refuse containers for every five (5) persons dwelling
therein (owners of two-family dwellings not located on separate floors shall
provide 2 standard refuse containers for each living unit).
         c.   In addition, it shall be the duty of the owner, lessor, lessee,
occupant, manager or agent of every multiple-dwelling unit of three (3) or more
living units to provide and maintain, in good condition and repair, the
following minimum sanitary dumpster indicated for the number of living units or
persons (whichever is greater):
 
Persons Living Or Dwelling Units Sanitary Dumpster Capacity
3       12 or under              1 yard
4 to 6  13 to 27                 11/2 yards
7 to 12 28 to 48                 2 yards
Over 12                         In proportion to the above
 
      3.   Occupational Units: It shall be the duty of the occupant of every
occupational unit to provide and maintain, in good condition and repair, not
less than two (2) standard refuse containers.
      4.   Living Units: It shall be the duty of every occupant of a living
unit to provide at least one standard refuse container for his own use.
      5.   Sanitary Dumpsters: The occupant of every building where refuse is
removed at the occupant's expense shall provide a sufficient number of sanitary
dumpsters for the temporary storage of all refuse accumulating between
collections.
      6.   Number Determined By Health Officer: The sufficiency of the number
of refuse containers required shall be the determination of the Health Officer.
(1985 Code § 4-4-3-1)
      7.   Minimum Requirements: The requirements of this subsection are
minimum requirements, and in cases where such minimum is inadequate, additional
refuse containers or dumpsters shall be provided as herein directed to avoid
overflow and spilling. These requirements shall be in addition to the Property
Maintenance Code and the Rental Residential Housing Code adopted in section
9-7-1 of this Code, whichever is more stringent. (1985 Code § 4-4-3-1; amd.
2016 Code)
   B.   Location: The standard container shall be placed in the following
manner:
      1.   Except for collections, all refuse containers or dumpsters shall be
located on private property concealed as nearly as practical from public view.
      2.   For alley collections, all refuse containers or dumpsters shall be
located at the alley lot line on the premises served so as to be immediately
accessible to refuse collection vehicles. It shall be the duty of the owner,
his manager or agent, or the lessor, lessee or occupant to provide suitable
space at the alley line for such containers. (1985 Code § 4-4-3-1)
      3.   For curb or street collections, all refuse containers or dumpsters
shall be located at the curb or street line (but not on the pavement) not
earlier than five o'clock (5:00) P.M. preceding the designated day of
collection and removed to the private property not later than six o'clock (6:
00) P.M. of such day of refuse collection. The placing of refuse containers
from six o'clock (6:00) P.M. on Friday to six o'clock (6:00) P.M. on Sunday or
from six o'clock (6:00) P.M. preceding a holiday to six o'clock (6:00) P.M. on
the day before collection is prohibited. (1985 Code § 4-4-3-1; amd. Ord. 05-18,
6-13-2005)
      4.   No container used for the storage, collection and removal of garbage
or other refuse shall be placed so as to constitute a nuisance to adjacent
property or the occupants thereof.
   C.   Use Requirements And Restrictions:
      1.   It shall be the duty of the occupant of every single dwelling,
multiple dwelling, living unit or occupational unit, to cause all refuse
produced therein to be deposited in the refuse containers. It shall be unlawful
for any person other than the owner, his manager or agent, or the lessor,
lessee or occupant of the premises served by a refuse container to deposit or
cause to be deposited therein any article or thing whatsoever.
      2.   All refuse which is placed for collection service in or outside of
the building must be kept in standard refuse containers.
      3.   It shall be unlawful for any person to deposit in any standard
refuse container any article or thing except "refuse" as defined in section
5-4-1 of this chapter.
      4.   It shall be unlawful to cause garbage or refuse to overflow or spill
over refuse containers. It shall be unlawful to remove the cover of or keep
uncovered any refuse container, except for placing garbage or refuse therein or
emptying the same. No scavenger or person removing refuse shall allow any
collectible refuse to spill or remain in the collection area after collection.
(1985 Code § 4-4-3-1)
5-4-4: PERMIT TO DUMP REFUSE:
   A.   No person shall dump or deposit anywhere within the Village, except at
such a place as may be authorized by the Village Board of Trustees by a written
permit, any garbage, ashes, refuse, miscellaneous waste, manure or other
substance that may contain disease carrying germs or be scattered by the wind,
or decompose or become filthy, noxious or unhealthy. Such dumping without a
permit is hereby declared to be a nuisance. It shall also be unlawful to dump
or deposit any waste matter upon private property unless the written consent of
the owner or his authorized agent shall first be obtained and filed with the
building inspector and a permit obtained from the Commissioner.
Whenever application shall have been made for a permit and the written consent
of the owner of the property in question shall have been filed as herein
required, the building inspector shall give notice in writing to the village
president where such dumping is to be done, that such application has been
made. Such application shall then be held in abeyance until the next regular
meeting of the board of trustees. In case action thereon is taken by the board
of trustees, the building inspector shall issue the permit if the dumping
privileges so requested will not constitute a nuisance and the applicant
executes a bond, with good and sufficient sureties approved by the building
inspector, to the village in the penal sum of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00)
conditioned that the applicant will comply with the regulations of this code
and the rules and regulations of the building inspector pertaining to the
dumping of the above mentioned substances. Such permit shall not authorize any
person to dump any of the said substances on private property above the street
grade.
   B.   "Refuse", for the purpose of this subsection, is defined as any garbage
or other discarded materials. (1985 Code § 4-4-4)
      1.   It shall be unlawful for any person to abandon, place, leave, dump
or deposit any refuse; junk; waste material; junked, wrecked, abandoned or
disabled vehicles, or any part thereof; or waste byproduct on any premises in
the village without first having secured a permit from the village to do so, or
in violation of section 21 of the environmental protection act 1  or of any
regulation or rule of the state environmental protection agency. (1985 Code §
4-4-4; amd. 2016 Code)
      2.   It shall be unlawful for any owner, lessor, lessee or occupant of
any premises to allow or permit any person to abandon, place, leave, dump or
deposit any refuse, junk, waste material, disabled vehicle or waste byproduct
on any premises in the village without a permit.
      3.   It shall be unlawful for any owner, lessor, lessee or occupant of
any premises to permit to remain on the premises or permit the accumulation on
any premises of any such refuse; junk; waste material; junked, wrecked,
abandoned or disabled vehicles, or any part thereof; or waste byproduct dumped
or deposited on the premises without a permit. (1985 Code § 4-4-4)
   C.   Any person who violates any provision of this section shall be subject
to a fine of not less than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) nor more than
that as allowed by state statute. (2016 Code)
 
Notes
1 1. 415 ILCS 5/21.
5-4-5: PROHIBITED ACCUMULATIONS AND DISPOSAL:
   A.   Generally:
      1.   No person shall throw, cast, deposit, damage, lay, place or scatter
in or upon any public way or any park property or appurtenance thereto any
placard, handbill, pamphlet, circular, book, notice, paper of any kind, coal,
ashes, dust, manure, rubbish, garbage, material, trees, shrubs, refuse matter
or article or thing of any kind.
      2.   It is unlawful for any person to dump, deposit or place any garbage,
rubbish, trash, litter or refuse upon real property owned or leased by another
without the consent of the owner, lessee or person in possession of such real
property.
      3.   It shall be unlawful for any person to throw, dump or deposit upon
any public way, or on private property not leased or owned by him or without
the consent of the owner or lessee, any garbage, refuse, container, paper,
waste, glass article, broken glass, nails, tacks, sharp metal objects or other
article or material. It shall be the duty of every owner or person in
possession or control of any motor vehicle, the glass or metal parts from which
are broken and dropped upon any public way, to promptly remove such broken
glass and metal parts and restore the public way to a condition safe for
automotive and pedestrian traffic.
   B.   Dumping Grass Or Rubbish: It shall be unlawful for any person to dump
or deposit, or cause to be dumped or deposited, rubbish, any grass, leaves,
branches, or any other things in the roadway, parkway, sidewalk, walkway or
gutter of any public street in the village, or on private property without the
consent of the owner. For the purpose of this subsection, the term "rubbish"
shall mean and include ashes, garbage, refuse of any kind, tins, bottles, glass
containers, unused food parcels, papers or any other inert material commonly
known as litter. (1985 Code § 4-4-5)
   C.   Windblown Refuse: It shall be unlawful to deposit or leave any refuse
or material in such a place or condition that it can be blown by the wind so as
to be scattered or cause clouds of dust or particles; and it shall be unlawful
to permit the escape of soot, ashes or other solid products or results of
combustion so as to be windblown or scattered. (1985 Code § 4-4-5; amd. 2016
Code)
5-4-6: BUILDING CONSTRUCTION:
   A.   Rubbish or discarded building materials shall not be stored nor allowed
to accumulate within a building or in the immediate vicinity, but shall be
removed from the premises as rapidly as practicable. Combustible waste and
rubbish shall be removed at least daily. Dry material or rubbish shall be
wetted down to prevent dust or prevent dust from being blown about. (1985 Code
§ 4-4-6; amd. 2016 Code)
After the foundation is poured and approved, a refuse container shall be
provided, and no construction shall proceed unless such foundation is approved
and said container is provided.
   B.   It shall be unlawful for any person engaged in or conducting in the
village the business of roofing buildings to throw dirt or roofing refuse from
the roof of any building upon any public way or upon adjoining property while
repairing or renewing roofs. Every person engaged in or conducting in the
village the business of roofing buildings shall remove the dirt and roofing
refuse from the roofs by lowering it in buckets or containers, or with ropes,
pulleys or other mechanical devices while repairing or renewing roofs. (1985
Code § 4-4-6)
5-4-7: OFFENSIVE, UNWHOLESOME MATERIALS:
   A.   Generally: It shall be unlawful for any person to dump, deposit or
burn, or allow to be dumped, deposited or burned, within the distance of one
mile beyond the corporate limits of the village any garbage, ashes, refuse,
miscellaneous wastes, manure or any other substance that may cause disease,
germs, vermin, or be scattered by the wind, or cause smoke or nauseous gases,
or be decomposed, or become filthy or noxious, cause offensive odors, or be
unhealthful or unwholesome. Any such unlawful acts or the conducting of any
business or establishment doing any such acts is hereby declared to be a
nuisance. (1985 Code § 4-4-7)
   B.   Receiving, Loading Or Depositing Prohibited: No person shall use or
occupy any place for the receipt, loading or dumping of manure, offal, garbage
or any other offensive or nauseous substance.
   C.   Animal Bedding: No person shall place or cause to be placed upon any
public way, or upon the roof of any building, or upon the surface of any lot or
parcel of ground, any straw, hay, shavings or other substance which has been
used as bedding for animals for the purpose of drying such substance or storing
the same. (1985 Code § 4-4-7; amd. 2016 Code)
   D.   Decaying Animal Matter: It shall be unlawful for any person having the
ownership or control of any animal matter within the village which is in the
process of decay so as to be offensive or dangerous to the public health to
permit the same to remain within the village or within one mile of the limits
thereof while in such condition more than twelve (12) hours after such animal
matter shall have come into such offensive or dangerous condition, whether it
be at an establishment for the rendering or changing the character thereof or
not. (1985 Code § 4-4-7)
   E.   Offensively Saturated Ground: No ground or material filled with
offensive matter or substance that will emit or allow to arise through or from
the same, any offensive smell or deleterious exhalation shall be opened or
turned up, or the surface thereof removed. It shall be unlawful for any owner
or occupant to maintain, use or occupy any saturated ground which emits
offensive smells or is dangerous to health. (1985 Code § 4-4-7; amd. 2016 Code)
5-4-8: SANITARY LANDFILLS PROHIBITED:
Sanitary landfill operations in the village or within the distance of one mile
beyond the corporate limits of the village are prohibited. (1985 Code § 4-4-10;
amd. 2016 Code)
5-4-9: NUISANCE DECLARED; ABATEMENT AND ENFORCEMENT:
   A.   Any violation of any of the provisions of this chapter shall be deemed
to be a nuisance and may be summarily removed, abated or prevented. In the
event that such nuisance is removed, abated or prevented at the expense or cost
to the village, then the village may recover the cost or expense of the same in
any proceeding in any court in the state of Illinois.
   B.   The offenses herein enumerated shall not prevent the enforcement of any
of the nuisances provided in chapter 3 of this title, but the offenses
enumerated herein shall be in addition thereto. (1985 Code § 4-4-11)
ARTICLE A. COLLECTORS OF GARBAGE AND REFUSE
SECTION:
5-4A-1: License And Certificate Requirements
5-4A-2: Collection Vehicles
5-4A-3: Noise Control; Hours Of Operation
5-4A-4: Refuse Collection; Location Of Containers
5-4A-5: Dropping Refuse From Vehicles
5-4A-1: LICENSE AND CERTIFICATE REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   License Requirements:
      1.   No person shall conduct the business of a scavenger or engage in the
business of picking up "refuse" as defined in section
5-4-1 of this chapter, nor be let out for hire to remove any such refuse,
without first securing a license therefor. The provisions of this section shall
not apply, however, to contractors or any other persons engaged in the building
trades who are removing refuse from building sites in their own vehicles.
      2.   Licenses for scavengers shall be restricted to one license per every
five hundred (500) inhabitants. (1985 Code § 4-4A-1)
   B.   Certificate Of Insurance Requirements:
      1.   As a condition to the issuance of a license under this section, each
applicant shall file a certificate of insurance issued by an insurance carrier
licensed to do business in the state of Illinois that evidences insurance
covering the applicant against public liability and property damage with limits
of liability not less than the following:
         a.   Personal injury:
            (1)   Each person: One million dollars ($1,000,000.00).
            (2)   Each occurrence: One million dollars ($1,000,000.00).
         b.   Property damage:
            (1)   Each person: One million dollars ($1,000,000.00).
            (2)   Each occurrence: One million dollars ($1,000,000.00).
      2.   Each such certificate shall have an endorsement to the effect that
such insurance may not be canceled by the insurer thereof without at least ten
(10) days' prior written notice to the village.
      3.   Further, said certificate of insurance shall include the village of
Hodgkins as additional insured. Each such application shall also contain a
clause that said applicant will indemnify the village for any costs in its
defense of actions arising out of the conduct of the applicant and hold the
village harmless for any damages that may be assessed against the village
pursuant to said action. (Ord. 87-2, 3-9-1987)
5-4A-2: COLLECTION VEHICLES:
   A.   Use Restrictions; Condition: No person owning or controlling any
vehicle used for carrying or transporting any garbage, ashes, miscellaneous
waste or manure shall cause or permit such vehicle when in use for such purpose
to stand or remain before or near any building, structure or premises occupied
by any person; nor shall any person using any such vehicle cause or permit an
unreasonable or unnecessary length of time to occur in and about the loading or
unloading of any such vehicle when in use for such purposes, or cause or permit
an unreasonable or unnecessary length of time to be used in passing along any
public way; nor shall any person cause or permit any such cart or vehicle to be
in a condition needlessly or unnecessarily filthy or offensive.
   B.   Disinfection; Storage Regulations: Any person owning or controlling any
refuse vehicle shall cause all such vehicles, and all implements used in
connection with the loading or unloading thereof, when not in use, to be stored
and kept in such place and in such manner as not to create a nuisance, and
shall cause all such vehicles and implements to be thoroughly disinfected and
put in an inoffensive condition when so stored or not in use. Such vehicles and
implements shall be thoroughly disinfected at least once a week, whether in use
or not, unless the same shall not have been used since the last disinfection
thereof. (1985 Code § 4-4A-2)
5-4A-3: NOISE CONTROL; HOURS OF OPERATION:
The operations and vehicles used for refuse collection shall conform to the
following:
   A.   All used vehicles shall conform to standards for motor vehicles of that
class set forth in the environmental control ordinance of Cook County, article
IX, "noise and vibration control".
   B.   Actual contract hours involved in the pick up of refuse and all other
solid wastes are limited to between the period of seven o'clock (7:00) A.M. and
six o'clock (6:00) P.M. on weekdays. There shall be no pick up on Saturdays or
Sundays, except as provided herein.
   C.   No scavenger truck picking up refuse on the village streets or private
property shall exceed in noise more than seventy (70) decibels, as measured at
a distance of fifty feet (50') from the centerline of travel opposite the
source of the noise under test procedures and instruments adopted in subsection
10-3-5B of this code. (1985 Code § 4-4A-3)
5-4A-4: REFUSE COLLECTION; LOCATION OF CONTAINERS:
   A.   All refuse containers, except plastic bags, shall be thoroughly emptied
and returned to the area where located at the time of collection. No refuse
container shall be located on a public street, roadway or sidewalk.
   B.   No scavenger shall allow any collectible refuse to spill or remain in
the collection area after collection. (1985 Code § 4-4A-4)
5-4A-5: DROPPING REFUSE FROM VEHICLES:
No person owning or controlling any refuse vehicle shall cause or permit any
such vehicle to be so loaded, to be in such defective condition, so out of
repair, of such faulty construction or so improperly driven or managed that any
garbage, ashes, refuse, miscellaneous waste or manure with which such vehicle
is loaded shall drop or fall on any public way or other place. Such vehicle and
any box, can or other receptacle carried thereon or therein, and in which any
of the substances described in this section shall be carried shall be so
constructed as to be strong and practically airtight and watertight so as to
prevent the same from emitting any odor and so as to prevent any part of the
contents or load thereof from falling, leaking or spilling therefrom. It shall
be the duty of every person in possession or control of any such vehicle to
replace, at once onto such vehicle, any part of the contents thereof which
shall or may have fallen, dropped or spilled from such vehicle, or from any box
or receptacle conveyed thereon, upon any public way or other place. (1985 Code
§ 4-4A-5)
CHAPTER 5
RODENT CONTROL
SECTION:
5-5-1: Definition
5-5-2: Ratproofing Required
5-5-3: Preventive Measures
5-5-4: Destruction Of Rats
5-5-5: Enforcement
5-5-1: DEFINITION:
For the purpose of this chapter, the term "ratproofing" shall consist of
closing unnecessary openings with concrete, sheet iron or other types of
material impervious to rats in building foundations and under and around doors,
windows, vents and other places which could provide means of entry for rats in
and under buildings. (1985 Code § 4-5-1)
5-5-2: RATPROOFING REQUIRED:
The owner of any premises upon which buildings are located shall eliminate the
rat harborage from within and under such buildings by some suitable and
customary method. (1985 Code § 4-5-2)
5-5-3: PREVENTIVE MEASURES:
   A.   Clean Premises; Harborage Areas Elevated: All premises, improved or
unimproved, and all open lots, areas, streets, sidewalks and alleys shall be
kept clean and free of all rubbish and material that might serve as harborage
for rats; and all lumber, boxes, barrels and loose iron, scrap metal, auto
bodies, as well as all other material that may be permitted to remain thereon
and that may be used as harborage for rats shall be placed on supports and
elevated from the ground with a clear intervening space of twelve inches (12")
beneath.
   B.   Food Storage: All food products for human or domestic animal
consumption, whether kept for sale or for any purpose, shall be protected so as
to prevent rats from gaining access thereto or coming into contact therewith.
   C.   Garbage Disposal: All garbage, decayed or spoiled vegetables, meats,
cereals, fruits or other similar material unfit for human or domestic animal
consumption, but edible to rats, shall be stored in garbage containers as
required in chapter 4 of this title. (1985 Code § 4-5-3)
5-5-4: DESTRUCTION OF RATS:
   A.   Destruction Required: Whenever rat holes, burrows or any other evidence
of rat infestation is found on any premises or in any building within the
village, it shall be the duty of the owner to use all methods necessary to
destroy the rats or cause the rats to be destroyed. (1985 Code § 4-5-4)
   B.   Cost Of Extermination: The cost of rat extermination shall be charged
to the owner, occupant or person interested in the premises as provided in 65
Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-20-8. (1985 Code § 4-5-4; amd. 2016 Code)
5-5-5: ENFORCEMENT:
   A.   Notice Of Violation: Whenever a premises is found to be rat infested or
to be maintained in violation of this chapter, a notice in writing signed by
the health officer shall be served upon the owner. Said notice shall state
wherein such premises has violated this chapter and the requirements for
correction and shall be served on the owner personally or by mail.
   B.   Abatement: It shall be unlawful to maintain a rat harborage. Any owner,
his manager or agent, any lessee, lessor, occupant or person who maintains his
premises or building in violation of the requirements of this chapter shall be
deemed guilty of maintaining a rat harborage. The health officer may declare
the maintenance of such rat harborage a nuisance and summarily abate the same
as provided in subsection
 5-1-4C of this title. (1985 Code § 4-5-5)
CHAPTER 6
FOOD DEALERS
ARTICLE A. RETAIL FOOD ESTABLISHMENTS
SECTION:
5-6A-1: Rules And Regulations
5-6A-2: Permit, License Or Certificate Required; Compliance With Provisions
5-6A-3: Application For Permit, License Or Certificate; Issuance
5-6A-4: Suspension Or Revocation Of Permit, License Or Certificate
5-6A-5: Service Of Notices
5-6A-6: Hearings
5-6A-7: Examination And Condemnation Of Food
5-6A-8: Infected Employee Suspects
5-6A-9: Inspections
5-6A-10: Plans For Construction Or Remodel; Inspections
5-6A-11: Inspection Costs
5-6A-12: Conditional License Or Permit
5-6A-13: Penalties
5-6A-1: RULES AND REGULATIONS:
The issuance, suspension and revocation of permits, licenses or certificates to
operate retail food establishments; the prohibiting of sale of unsound or
mislabeled food or drink; and the enforcement of this article shall be
regulated in accordance with section 5-6A-2 of this article concerning the
compliance procedures. The inspection of food service establishments shall be
regulated in accordance with the 1991 and all subsequent editions or amendments
to the Illinois department of public health's publication currently titled
"Food Service Sanitation Rules And Regulations", on file with the secretary of
state. The inspection of retail food stores shall be regulated in accordance
with the 1989 and all subsequent editions or amendments to the Illinois
department of public health's publication currently titled "Retail Food Store
Sanitation Rules And Regulations", on file with the secretary of state. Three
(3) copies of each of the rules and regulations stated herein are on file in
the office of the village clerk. (Ord. 92-6, 3-9-1992)
5-6A-2: PERMIT, LICENSE OR CERTIFICATE REQUIRED; COMPLIANCE WITH PROVISIONS:
No person shall operate a food establishment who does not have a valid permit,
license or certificate issued thereto by the village. Only a person who
complies with the requirements of this article shall be entitled to receive or
retain such a permit, license or certificate. Permits, licenses or certificates
are not transferable. A valid permit, license or certificate shall be posted in
every food establishment. (Ord. 92-6, 3-9-1992)
5-6A-3: APPLICATION FOR PERMIT, LICENSE OR CERTIFICATE; ISSUANCE:
   A.   Any person desiring to operate a food establishment shall make written
application for a permit, license or certificate on forms provided by the
village. Such application shall include the name and address of each applicant,
the location and type of the proposed food establishment, and the signature of
each applicant.
   B.   Prior to approval of an application for a permit, license or
certificate, the village and the Cook County department of public health shall
inspect the proposed food establishment to determine compliance with the
requirements of this article.
   C.   The village shall issue a permit, license or certificate to the
applicant if its inspection reveals that the proposed food establishment
complies with the requirements of this article. (Ord. 92-6, 3-9-1992)
5-6A-4: SUSPENSION OR REVOCATION OF PERMIT, LICENSE OR CERTIFICATE:
   A.   Suspension:
      1.   Summary Suspension: The village may, without warning, notice, or
hearing, suspend any permit, license or certificate to operate a food
establishment if the holder of the permit, license or certificate does not
comply with the requirements of this article, or if the operation of the food
establishment otherwise constitutes a substantial hazard to public health.
Suspension is effective upon service of the notice required by subsection B2 of
this section. When a permit, license or certificate is suspended, food
operations shall immediately cease. Whenever a permit, license or certificate
is suspended, the holder of the permit, license, or certificate shall be
afforded an opportunity for hearing within twenty (20) days of receipt of a
request for hearing.
      2.   Notice Of Suspension: Whenever a permit, license or certificate is
suspended, the holder of the permit, license or certificate, or the person in
charge, shall be notified in writing that the permit, license or certificate
is, upon service of the notice, immediately suspended and that an opportunity
for hearing will be provided if a written request for hearing is filed with the
village by the holder of the permit, license or certificate within ten (10)
days. If no written request for hearing is filed within ten (10) days, the
suspension is sustained. The village may end the suspension at any time if
reasons for suspension no longer exist.
   B.   Revocation:
      1.   Authority To Revoke: The village may, after providing opportunity
for hearing, revoke the permit, license or certificate for serious or repeated
violations of any of the requirements of this article or for interference with
the village or the Cook County department of public health in the performance
of duty.
      2.   Notice Of Revocation: Prior to revocation, the village shall notify,
in writing, the holder of the permit, license or certificate, or the person in
charge, of the specific reason(s) for which the permit, license or certificate
is to be revoked and that the permit, license or certificate shall be revoked
at the end of ten (10) days following service of such notice unless a written
request for hearing is filed with the village by the holder of the permit,
license or certificate within such ten (10) day period. If no request for
hearing is filed within the ten (10) day period, the revocation of the permit,
license or certificate becomes final. (Ord. 92-6, 3-9-1992)
      3.   Application After Revocation: Whenever a revocation of a permit,
license or certificate has become final, the holder of the revoked permit,
license or certificate may make written application for a new permit, license
or certificate; provided, however, such application shall be no earlier than
six (6) months from the date of revocation. (Ord. 92-6, 3-9-1992; amd. 2016
Code)
5-6A-5: SERVICE OF NOTICES:
A notice provided in this article is properly served when it is delivered to
the holder of the permit, license or certificate, or the person in charge, or
when it is sent by registered or certified mail, return receipt requested, to
the last known address of the holder of the permit, license or certificate. A
copy of the notice shall be filed in the records of the village. (Ord. 92-6, 3-
9-1992)
5-6A-6: HEARINGS:
The hearings provided in this article shall be conducted by the president and
three (3) members of the board of trustees designated by the president at a
time and place designated by the president. Any oral testimony given at a
hearing shall be reported verbatim, and the presiding officer shall make
provision for sufficient copies of the transcript. The village shall make a
final finding based upon the complete hearing record and shall sustain, modify
or rescind any notice or order considered in the hearing. A written report of
the hearing decision shall be furnished to the holder of the permit, license or
certificate by the village. (Ord. 92-6, 3-9-1992)
5-6A-7: EXAMINATION AND CONDEMNATION OF FOOD:
Food may be examined or sampled by the Cook County department of public health
as often as necessary for enforcement of this article. The Cook County
department of public health may, upon written notice to the owner or person in
charge, specifying with particularity the reasons therefor, place a hold order
on any food which it believes is in violation of section 750.100, 750.110,
760.100, or 760.110 of the Illinois department of public health's publication
currently titled "Food Service Sanitation Rules And Regulations" or "Retail
Food Store Sanitation Rules And Regulations", respectively, or any other
section of this article. The Cook County department of public health shall tag,
label, or otherwise identify any food subject to the hold order. No food
subject to a hold order shall be used, served, or moved from the establishment.
The Cook County department of public health shall permit storage of the food
under conditions specified in the hold order, unless storage is not possible
without risk to the public health, in which case, immediate destruction shall
be ordered and accomplished. The hold order shall state that a request for
hearing may be filed within ten (10) days and that if no hearing is requested,
the food shall be destroyed. If a request for hearing is received, the hearing
shall be held within twenty (20) days after receipt of the request. On the
basis of evidence produced at the hearing, the hold order may be vacated, or
the owner or person in charge of the food may be directed by written order to
denature or destroy such food or to bring it into compliance with the
provisions of this article. (Ord. 92-6, 3-9-1992)
5-6A-8: INFECTED EMPLOYEE SUSPECTS:
When the Cook County department of public health has reasonable cause to
suspect possible disease transmission by an employee of a food establishment,
it may secure a morbidity history of the suspected employee or make any other
investigations as indicated and shall take appropriate action. The Cook County
department of public health may require any or all of the following measures:
   A.   The immediate exclusion of the employee from employment in food
establishments.
   B.   The immediate closing of the food establishment concerned until, in the
opinion of the Cook County department of public health, no further danger of
disease outbreak exists.
   C.   Restriction of the employee's services to some area of the
establishment where there would be no danger of transmitting disease.
   D.   Adequate medical and laboratory examination of the employee and of
other employees and of his or their body discharges. (Ord. 92-6, 3-9-1992)
5-6A-9: INSPECTIONS:
   A.   Frequency: An inspection of a food establishment shall be performed at
least once every six (6) months. Additional inspections of the food
establishment shall be performed as often as necessary for the enforcement of
this article.
   B.   Right Of Access: Duly authorized representatives of the village or the
Cook County department of public health, after proper identification, shall be
permitted to enter any food establishment at any reasonable time for the
purpose of making inspections to determine compliance with this article. The
representatives shall be permitted to examine the records of the establishment
to obtain information pertaining to food and supplies purchased, received, or
used. (Ord. 92-6, 3-9-1992)
   C.   Report Of Inspections: Whenever an inspection of a food establishment
is made, the findings shall be recorded on the inspection report form provided
by the village. The inspection report form shall summarize the requirements of
this article and shall set forth a weighted point value for each requirement.
Inspection remarks should be written to reference, by item number, the item
violated and should state the correction to be made. The rating score of the
establishment shall be the total of the weighted point values for all
violations, subtracted from 100. A copy of the completed inspection report form
shall be furnished to the person in charge of the establishment at the
conclusion of the inspection. The completed inspection report form is a public
document that shall be made available through the office of the village clerk
for public disclosure to any person who requests it, according to law. (Ord.
92-6, 3-9-1992; amd. 2016 Code)
   D.   Correction Of Violations:
      1.   The completed inspection report form shall specify a reasonable
period of time for the correction of the violations found, and correction of
the violations shall be accomplished within the period specified, in accordance
with the following provisions:
         a.   If an imminent health hazard exists, such as complete lack of
refrigeration or sewage backup into the establishment, the establishment shall
immediately cease food operations. Operations shall not be resumed until
authorized by the Cook County department of public health.
         b.   All violations of 4 or 5 point weighted items shall be corrected
as soon as possible, but in any event, within ten (10) days following
inspection. A follow up inspection shall be conducted to confirm correction at
the discretion of the Cook County department of public health.
         c.   All 1 or 2 point weighted items shall be corrected as soon as
possible, but in any event, by the time of the next routine inspection.
         d.   When the rating score of the establishment is less than 60, the
establishment shall initiate corrective action on all identified violations
within forty eight (48) hours. One or more reinspections will be conducted at
reasonable time intervals to assure correction.
         e.   In the case of temporary food establishments, all violations
shall be corrected within twenty four (24) hours. If violations are not
corrected within twenty four (24) hours, the establishment shall immediately
cease food operations until authorized to resume by the Cook County department
of public health.
      2.   The inspection report shall state that failure to comply with any
time limits for corrections may result in cessation of food operations. An
opportunity for hearing on the inspection findings or the time limits, or both,
will be provided if a written request is filed with the village within ten (10)
days following cessation of operations. If a request for hearing is received, a
hearing shall be held within twenty (20) days of receipt of the request.
      3.   Whenever a food establishment is required under the provisions of
this article to cease operations, it shall not resume operations until it is
shown on reinspection that conditions responsible for the order to cease
operations no longer exists. Opportunity for reinspections shall be offered
within a reasonable time. (Ord. 92-6, 3-9-1992)
5-6A-10: PLANS FOR CONSTRUCTION OR REMODEL; INSPECTIONS:
   A.   Whenever a food establishment is constructed or extensively remodeled
and whenever an existing structure is converted to use as a food establishment,
properly prepared plans and specifications for construction, remodeling, or
conversion shall be submitted to the village and the Cook County department of
public health for review and approval before construction, remodeling or
conversion is begun. The plans and specifications shall indicate the proposed
layout, arrangement, mechanical plans, and construction materials of work areas
and the type and model of proposed fixed equipment and facilities. The village
and the Cook County department of public health shall approve the plans and
specifications if they meet the requirements of this article. No food
establishment shall be constructed, extensively remodeled, or converted except
in accordance with plans and specifications approved by the village and the
Cook County department of public health.
   B.   Whenever plans and specifications are required by subsection A of this
section to be submitted to the village and the Cook County department of public
health, the village and the Cook County department of public health shall
inspect the food establishment prior to the start of operation to determine
compliance with the approved plans and specifications and with the requirements
of this article. (Ord. 92-6, 3-9-1992)
5-6A-11: INSPECTION COSTS:
The cost of any and all inspections required under this article shall be borne
by the retail food and beverage establishment. (Ord. 97-7, 3-10-1997)
5-6A-12: CONDITIONAL LICENSE OR PERMIT:
When structural, plumbing and electrical, ventilation, or similar such effects
exist in an established food facility that may require significant expenditures
to correct, but are not considered to be imminent health hazards, a conditional
license or permit may be granted at the discretion of the health authority.
Under no circumstances will a conditional license or permit be issued for more
than two (2) consecutive twelve (12) month periods. The purpose of the
conditional license or permit is to allow a reasonable period of time for
correction of existing defects. (Ord. 92-6, 3-9-1992)
5-6A-13: PENALTIES:
Any person violating the provisions of this article shall be fined as provided
in section
1-4-1 of this code for each offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed
committed on each day during or on which a violation continues. The village
shall have the right to enjoin any person or establishment in the event
violations occur on a continuing basis. (Ord. 92-6, 3-9-1992; amd. 2016 Code)
ARTICLE B. FOOD VENDORS
SECTION:
5-6B-1: Licensing Provisions
5-6B-2: Street Dispensing Prohibitions
5-6B-3: Littering
5-6B-4: Violations
5-6B-1: LICENSING PROVISIONS:
   A.   License Required; Conditions: A person may be given a license to peddle
foods in a sealed, packaged container upon roadways of the streets of the
village upon the following conditions:
      1.   Compliance With Health Regulations: The person shall comply with all
the health and other regulations set forth in the ordinances of the village and
regulations promulgated by the state of Illinois.
      2.   Devices Creating Sound: No other sound announcement of the presence
of such person or vehicle shall be used, except manually operated chimes, and
no amplification device, mechanical or electronic, shall be used. In any event,
the sound from said manually operated chimes shall not become loud or
intolerable to any person, nor shall it be greater than sixty seven (67)
decibels at the source of the sound based on sound levels measured with a sound
level meter, according to standards prescribed by the American Standards
Association.
      3.   Food Sales:
         a.   The food being vended shall be in a sealed, packaged container.
         b.   All sales and delivery of wares shall be made and consummated by
the vendor on the street and outside the vehicle. Sales from any part of or out
of the vehicle, except as herein provided, are prohibited.
         c.   The practice of selling minor quantities of food from bulk is
prohibited.
      4.   Hours: Vending is prohibited between dusk and the hour of eleven
o'clock (11:00) A.M. of the following morning, prevailing time. (1985 Code § 4-
6-2-1)
   B.   License Fee: The annual license fee of such person or vehicle shall be
as set forth in section
4-1A-1 of this code. (1985 Code § 4-6-2-1; amd. 2016 Code)
   C.   Vehicle License: Each vehicle shall be separately licensed. (1985 Code
§ 4-6-2-1)
5-6B-2: STREET DISPENSING PROHIBITIONS:
   A.   The custom among merchants dealing in ice cream, ices, soda waters,
other soft drinks, hot dogs, hamburgers, hot tamales and similar unpackaged
foods, of delivery at the curb, in the street or upon the sidewalks or
roadways, their merchandise in paper cups, plates or other containers other
than in a sealed, packaged carton, has become a nuisance and a menace to
pedestrians traveling upon the roadway by reason of the depositing of such
cups, plates or other containers on the sidewalks and streets, and the delivery
of such commodities in containers upon the public streets, except in a sealed,
packaged container, anywhere on the streets is hereby declared to be a nuisance
and a menace.
   B.   No person dealing at retail in ice creams, soda waters and other soft
drinks, hot dogs, hamburgers, hot tamales or merchandise of like character
shall deliver the same upon the streets, sidewalks, alleys or other public ways
of the village.
   C.   The sale or disposition by any person of food, beverage, dairy
products, ice cream or any of its kindred products, in paper, cardboard or
other container, other than in a sealed, packaged container, known by such
person to be intended to be consumed by the buyer on the sidewalks, alleys or
at or near the place of business where such food or beverage is sold or
dispensed is hereby declared to be a nuisance and a danger to the health and
sanitation of the community.
   D.   No food dealer shall deliver any such goods to a person known to be a
runner or person employed to carry such goods from the place of business to
persons on the sidewalk, curb or street, and no such runner shall deliver any
such merchandise on the streets, sidewalks or alleys of the village. (1985 Code
§ 4-6-2-2)
5-6B-3: LITTERING:
No person shall litter, throw or drop any cup, plate or container upon a
sidewalk, crosswalk, roadway or any part of any public street, and such act is
hereby declared to be a nuisance and is unlawful. (1985 Code § 4-6-2-3)
5-6B-4: VIOLATIONS:
Any dealer in ice cream, ices, soda water or other soft drinks, hot dogs,
hamburgers, hot tamales and similar packaged food, or merchandise of like
character, who shall violate any of the provisions of this article shall be
guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be subject to having his license as such
dealer revoked by the village president; and any person littering, throwing or
dropping such cup, plate or container on the street, and any person acting as a
runner as herein prohibited, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. (1985 Code § 4-
6-2-4)
CHAPTER 7
ILLICIT DISCHARGE DETECTION AND ELIMINATION
SECTION:
5-7-1: Purpose And Intent
5-7-2: Definitions
5-7-3: Applicability And Interpretation
5-7-4: Administration And Enforcement Authority
5-7-5: Discharge Prohibitions And Exemptions
5-7-6: Industrial Or Construction Activity Discharges
5-7-7: Monitoring Discharges
5-7-8: Use Of Best Management Practices
5-7-9: Watercourse Protection
5-7-10: Notice Of Spills
5-7-11: Suspension Of MS4 Access
5-7-12: Enforcement And Penalties
5-7-1: PURPOSE AND INTENT:
The purpose of this chapter is to provide for the health, safety, and general
welfare of the citizens of the village through the regulation of nonstormwater
