      1.   It shall be unlawful for any person to falsely represent himself to
be an employee, officer or a member of any village agency or department
including, but not limited to, the fire, police, building, public works and the
emergency services and disaster departments.
      2.   It shall be unlawful for any person to falsely represent himself to
be an employee, officer or member of any school district, park district,
sanitary district, public health district, township, library district, county,
state or municipal corporation or body politic.
      3.   It shall be unlawful for any person to falsely represent himself to
be an employee, officer or member of any police, fire, fraternal, veteran,
charitable or not for profit organization.
      4.   It shall be unlawful for any person to exhibit or use in any manner
any decal, uniform, badge or insignia of any village, school district, park
district, sanitary district, public health district, township, library
district, county, state or municipal corporation or body politic; or any
fraternal, veteran, not for profit or charitable organization; or any
department or agency without its authorization.
   B.   Interfering With, Resisting An Officer: It shall be unlawful for any
person to wilfully interfere with, resist, delay, obstruct, molest or threaten
to molest any officer of the village in the exercise of his official duties.
   C.   Assistance To Police: It shall be unlawful for any citizen over the age
of eighteen (18) years to refuse or neglect to render assistance to any police
officer when called upon for such assistance or aid in the suppression of riot
or other unlawful assemblage or in the arrest of any person who has committed
an offense. (1985 Code § 5-5A-4)
6-5A-5: FRAUD:
   A.   False Pretenses: It shall be unlawful for any person to obtain any
food, drink, goods, wares or merchandise under false pretenses, or to enter any
public place and call for refreshments or other articles and receive and refuse
to pay for same, or depart without paying for or satisfying the person from
whom he received the food, goods, wares and merchandise.
   B.   Swindling: It shall be unlawful for any person who, by color or aid of
any trick or sleight of hand performance, or by fraud or by fraudulent scheme,
cards, dice or device, to win for himself or for another any money or property
or a representative of either. (1985 Code § 5-5A-5; amd. 2016 Code)
6-5A-6: PUBLIC INTOXICATION:
It shall be unlawful for any person to be in a state of intoxication or drugged
condition on any highway, street, alley, thoroughfare or public place, or in
any private house or place, if such person has become a danger to himself or to
others as a result of his intoxication. (1985 Code § 5-5A-6; amd. 2016 Code)
6-5A-7: ESCAPE; AID IN ESCAPE:
It shall be unlawful for any person convicted of any offense or in lawful
custody to escape or attempt to escape from custody, and it shall be unlawful
for any person to aid or assist any person to escape from lawful confinement or
to assist any person to escape from the custody of any peace officer. (1985
Code § 5-5A-7)
6-5A-8: FURNISHING ARTICLES TO PRISONERS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to furnish or attempt to furnish or take
into jail or to deliver or attempt to deliver to any prisoner therein confined,
or in the custody of any officer, any weapon, tool, intoxicating liquors, drug
or other article without the consent of the officer in charge. (1985 Code § 5-
5A-8)
6-5A-9: SPOUSAL AND CHILD ABUSE:
It shall be unlawful for any person to injure, beat or mistreat his or her
spouse, child, stepchild or apprentice, or other child under his care. (1985
Code § 5-5A-9; amd. 2016 Code)
6-5A-10: TRANSPORTING METAL ITEMS:
All rails, pillars and columns of iron, steel or other metal which are being
transported over and along the streets in any manner shall be so loaded as to
avoid causing loud noises and disturbing the peace and quiet of the streets.
(1985 Code § 5-5A-10)
ARTICLE B. OFFENSES AGAINST PROPERTY
SECTION:
6-5B-1: Damage To Property
6-5B-1-1: Injury And Damage To Property
6-5B-1-2: Trespass
6-5B-1-3: Petit Theft
6-5B-1-4: Billposting
6-5B-1-5: License Tags And Plates
6-5B-2: Use Of Public Ways And Property
6-5B-3: Fill Dirt Removal
6-5B-4: Barbed Wire And Electric Fences
6-5B-5: Jumping Trains
6-5B-6: Burglar Tools
6-5B-7: Graffiti
6-5B-1: DAMAGE TO PROPERTY:
6-5B-1-1:   INJURY AND DAMAGE TO PROPERTY:
   A.   Private Property:
      1.   No person shall cut, injure, mark or deface any building or property
not his own, or any tree, grass, shrub or walk in any square, street or park.
      2.   It shall be unlawful for any person to wilfully and maliciously
injure, deface, mutilate, remove, pull down, break, or in any manner interfere
with or molest or secrete or destroy any real or personal property belonging to
or under the control of any person. (1985 Code § 5-5B-1-1)
   B.   Public Property:
      1.   Any person who wilfully or carelessly breaks, damages, defaces or
destroys any sewer, culvert, catch basin, manhole, water pipe or hydrant laid
or placed in, upon or under any street, sidewalk, highway, thoroughfare or
public place within the village shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor.
      2.   No person shall injure, destroy, deface, or assist in injuring,
destroying or defacing, any bridge, fence, building, schoolhouse, house, public
building, street sign, sidewalk, tree, lamppost or any other kind of public
property.
   C.   Property Of Utilities: Any person who shall carelessly or maliciously
break, deface, disturb, interfere with, carry away or in any way injure or
destroy any electric light, globe or any part of or appurtenances to any lamp
or light of any kind used in or upon or about any street, alley or public place
or who shall carelessly or maliciously break, injure, destroy or in any way
disturb or interfere with any electric light, telephone line, or any
appurtenance thereto, at any place, shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor.
(1985 Code § 5-5B-1-1; amd. 2016 Code)
6-5B-1-2:   TRESPASS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to commit a trespass within the village
upon either public or private property. Without constituting any limitation
upon the provisions hereof, any of the following acts by any person shall be
deemed included among those that constitute trespass in violation of the
provisions of this section, and appropriate action may be taken hereunder at
any time to prevent or suppress any violation of this section and of the
following enumerated acts:
   A.   An entry upon the premises, or any part thereof, of another, including
any public property, in violation of a notice posted or exhibited at the main
entrance to said premises or at any point of approach or entry or in violation
of any notice, warning or protest given orally or in writing by any owner or
occupant thereof.
   B.   The pursuit of a course of conduct or action incidental to the making
of an entry upon the land of another in violation of a notice posted or
exhibited at the main entrance to said premises or at any point of approach or
entry, or in violation of any notice, warning or protest given orally or in
writing by any owner or occupant thereof.
   C.   A failure or refusal to depart from the premises of another in case of
being requested, either orally or in writing, to leave by any owner or occupant
thereof.
   D.   An entry into or upon any vehicle, aircraft or watercraft made without
the consent of the person having the right to the possession or control
thereof, or a failure or refusal to leave any such vehicle, aircraft or
watercraft after being requested to leave by the person having such right.
(1985 Code § 5-5B-1-2)
   E.   To take down any fence or to open any gate in or on the property of
another without the consent of the owner, occupant or person in charge thereof.
(1985 Code § 5-5B-1-2; amd. 2016 Code)
6-5B-1-3:   PETIT THEFT:
It shall be unlawful for any person to commit "petit theft" which is hereby
defined as a theft when the property taken is of a value of less than five
hundred dollars ($500.00). (1985 Code § 5-5B-1-3; amd. 2016 Code)
6-5B-1-4:   BILLPOSTING:
It shall be unlawful for any person to paste, post, paint, print or nail any
handbill, sign, poster, advertisement or notice of any kind on any curbstone,
flagstone or any other portion or part of any sidewalk; or upon any tree,
lamppost, hitchpost, telephone pole, or hydrant; or upon any private wall, door
or gate, without the consent in writing of the owner of the wall, door or gate;
provided, however, that this section shall not prevent posting by proper
village and county officials of election signs, polling place signs and other
signs or placards necessary under the law to the conduct of elections. (1985
Code § 5-5B-1-4; amd. 2016 Code)
6-5B-1-5:   LICENSE TAGS AND PLATES:
Every person who shall, without the consent of the owner or licensee, take,
carry away, detach or mutilate any metal plate, tag, badge or license worn by
or attached to any person, animal or vehicle or attached to any article,
substance or thing whatsoever as a mark of identification or otherwise in
compliance with the requirements of any provision of this code or other village
ordinance, shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. (1985 Code § 5-5B-1-5)
6-5B-2: USE OF PUBLIC WAYS AND PROPERTY:
No person shall, in the public ways or on public property:
   A.   Climb a tree or climb or walk upon any wall or fence.
   B.   Enter upon any portion where persons are prohibited from going, as
indicated by sign or notice.
   C.   Fish or bathe in any of the waters except such portions thereof as may
be designated for such purposes, and under such regulations as may be
prescribed by the village.
   D.   Enter upon any part which is in an unfinished state or under
construction. (1985 Code § 5-5B-2)
6-5B-3: FILL DIRT REMOVAL:
No person shall dig, cut or remove any soil, sod, gravel, sand or earth from
any street or other public place without a permit from the village or from any
premises not his own without the consent of the owner. (1985 Code § 5-5B-3;
amd. 2016 Code)
6-5B-4: BARBED WIRE AND ELECTRIC FENCES:
   A.   It shall be unlawful for any person to erect or maintain any electric
fence, any barbed wire fence or any fence which has spikes, barbs, sharply
pointed pickets, sharp projections or sharp protrusions; except, that barbed
wire is permitted on top of fencing around high voltage or high tension lines
maintained by a public utility and in a manufacturing district.
   B.   It is hereby prohibited to erect any barbed wire fence or fence having
spurs on the top, which fence is adjacent to a public street, sidewalk or
parkway. Fences over six feet (6') high with barbs or spurs are permitted,
however, such fences shall be not less than two feet (2') from the street right
of way line. (1985 Code § 5-5B-4)
6-5B-5: JUMPING TRAINS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to play on or about any railroad track,
depot, locomotive or car within the village, or climb upon or jump from any car
or train of cars, or from one car to another. It is the duty of the police
force to vigorously enforce this section, and all railroad employees shall be
empowered to arrest all persons found violating the same. (1985 Code § 5-5B-5)
6-5B-6: BURGLAR TOOLS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to have in his possession any key, tool,
instrument, device, or explosive suitable for use in breaking into a building,
house trailer, watercraft, aircraft, motor vehicle, railroad car, or any
depository designed for the safekeeping of property, or any part thereof, with
intent to enter any such place and with intent to commit a felony or theft as
described under Illinois law. (1985 Code § 5-5B-6; amd. 2016 Code)
6-5B-7: GRAFFITI:
   A.   Prohibited: It is unlawful to any person to inscribe, draw or otherwise
place upon the surface of any structure or wall that is privately or publicly
owned, any word, phrase, diagram, symbol, sketch or letters where the contents
thereof are visible to any member of the general public without the consent of
the owner and without compliance with village ordinances.
   B.   Penalties: Upon conviction for violation of the conduct prohibited in
subsection A of this section, there shall be imposed a fine of not less than
two hundred dollars ($200.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars
($750.00). In addition, a mandatory requirement shall be imposed by any court
finding a person guilty of violating the provisions of this section, as a
condition to any probation or supervision, that full and complete restitution
be made to the owner of the property for expenses incurred in the removal of
the material and repair of the structure or wall.
   C.   Removal And Restoration Requirements: It shall be the duty of the owner
of the structure or wall, upon inscription or representation prohibited in this
section, to remove such inscription or representation and to otherwise repair
or restore the structure or wall to its prior condition within three (3) days
from the occurrence of the offense. The owner of the property shall be entitled
to restitution and compensation for the direct costs incurred in the repair and
restoration of his property from any person convicted of the prohibited
activity upon the submission of receipts evidencing payments of such costs, and
provided the court entering the finding or conviction for the offense shall so
order. (Ord. 89-7, 5-22-1989; amd. 2016 Code)
ARTICLE C. OFFENSES AFFECTING PUBLIC HEALTH AND SAFETY
SECTION:
6-5C-1: Injurious Articles On Public Ways
6-5C-2: Throwing Missiles
6-5C-3: Expectorating In Public
6-5C-4: Abandoned Containers
6-5C-5: Reckless Skating Or Skateboarding
6-5C-1: INJURIOUS ARTICLES ON PUBLIC WAYS:
   A.   Materials On Thoroughfares: It shall be unlawful for any person to
deposit, place or allow to remain in or upon any public thoroughfare any
material or substance injurious to person or property.
   B.   Articles In Windows: It shall be unlawful for any person to place or
keep on any windowsill, porch or other projection above the first story of any
building abutting on any sidewalk, any article which might do injury by falling
upon any person on the sidewalk in front of such building, unless said article
be securely fastened or protected by screens. (1985 Code § 5-5C-1)
6-5C-2: THROWING MISSILES:
No person shall throw any stone or other missile upon or at any building,
railroad car, vehicle or other public or private property, or upon or at any
person in any street, avenue, alley, lane, public place or enclosed or
unenclosed ground, or aid or abet in the same. (1985 Code § 5-5C-2; amd. 2016
Code)
6-5C-3: EXPECTORATING IN PUBLIC:
It shall be unlawful for any person to expectorate or spit upon any public
property. (1985 Code § 5-5C-3; amd. 2016 Code)
6-5C-4: ABANDONED CONTAINERS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to abandon or discard in any place
accessible to children any refrigerator, icebox or ice chest, of a capacity of
one and one-half (11/2) cubic feet or more, which has an attached lid or door
which may be opened or fastened shut by means of an attached latch, and it
shall be unlawful for any owner, lessee or manager of such place to knowingly
permit such abandoned or discarded refrigerator, icebox or ice chest to remain
there in such condition. (1985 Code § 5-5C-5; amd. 2016 Code)
6-5C-5: RECKLESS SKATING OR SKATEBOARDING:
No person shall roller skate, ice skate, rollerblade, or ride a skateboard, or
use any other sporting equipment manufactured with rollers or blades, in a
reckless manner, or at a speed greater than is reasonable and proper, having
regard to the number of people and the use thereof, or so as to endanger life
or limb, or damage the property of any person; provided, however, that nothing
herein contained shall be construed to prohibit any exhibition of, or contests
in fast or fancy skating on such portions of any ice pond or surface used for
roller skating as may be set aside for that purpose by the board of trustees or
other regulatory body. (Ord. 93-22, 12-13-1993)
ARTICLE D. OFFENSES INVOLVING AMUSEMENTS
SECTION:
6-5D-1: Admission Fees; Fraudulently Avoiding Payment
6-5D-2: Sound Amplification
6-5D-3: Games And Athletic Events
6-5D-4: Picnics; Open Air Dances
6-5D-1: ADMISSION FEES; FRAUDULENTLY AVOIDING PAYMENT:
It shall be unlawful for any person fraudulently to enter, without payment of
the proper admission fee, any theater, ballroom, lecture hall, concert hall or
other place where admission fees are charged; provided, however, that nothing
herein contained shall be deemed to prohibit or restrict the free admission of
police officers engaged in the performance of police duties to any place of
public entertainment or amusement. (1985 Code § 5-5D-2)
6-5D-2: SOUND AMPLIFICATION:
   A.   Permit Requirements: It shall be unlawful for any person to maintain,
operate, use or employ any loudspeaker, electronically or mechanically
operated, producing sound, which sound is amplified and heard over any public
street, public place or private property other than the property of the person
so maintaining, operating, using or employing the same, without first having
obtained a permit. A permit shall be issued only for parades authorized by the
village board, political speeches and matters of public issue. The permit shall
be issued without fee and subject to the following restrictions:
      1.   No such amplification device shall be employed on or after eight
o'clock (8:00) P.M. on any prevailing day and eight o'clock (8:00) A.M. the
next day. (1985 Code § 5-5D-3)
      2.   No permittee shall use, operate or employ such device within a
radius of two (2) blocks of a place of worship when such place of worship is in
session, or within a radius of two (2) blocks of a school when such school is
in session. (1985 Code § 5-5D-3; amd. 2016 Code)
      3.   No permittee shall allow any lewd, obscene, profane, indecent
language or sounds, advertisement or false representation of any matter to
emanate from said device.
      4.   No permittee shall allow the noise from said sound device to be
amplified greater than is tolerable to the human ear by an ordinary person
within hearing distance and, in any event, no greater than the maximum levels
in a use district based on sound levels measured with a sound level meter as
set forth in subsection
10-3-5B of this code.
   B.   Loud Noises: It shall be unlawful for any person, at any time, to
maintain, operate, use or employ any electronic or mechanical amplification
device or to make or allow noises from any source whatsoever which may become
loud and intolerable to the ordinary person, or which sound or noise shall be
greater than the maximum levels based on sound levels in a use district
measured with a sound level meter as set forth in subsection
10-3-5B of this code. (1985 Code § 5-5D-3)
6-5D-3: GAMES AND ATHLETIC EVENTS:
   A.   No person shall engage in any athletic game or sport in the village
except such portions thereof as may be designated for that purpose by the board
of trustees and then only under such rules and regulations as may be prescribed
by said board.
   B.   It shall be unlawful for any person to play ball or throw any ball upon
any public thoroughfare in the village.
   C.   It is hereby prohibited to play any game or any sport or do any action
in the nature of a game upon the public streets. (1985 Code § 5-5D-4)
6-5D-4: PICNICS; OPEN AIR DANCES:
It shall be unlawful for any person to rent or use, or allow to be used, any
yard, ground, grove or other real estate within the village for public picnics
or open air dances to be conducted in such manner as to be an annoyance or
injury to the public. All public picnics or open air dances shall be subject to
the issuance of a permit by the village in accordance with the licensing and
permit provisions of this code. (1985 Code § 5-5D-5)
ARTICLE E. OFFENSES AFFECTING MORALS AND DECENCY
SECTION:
6-5E-1: Obscenity
6-5E-1-1: Definitions
6-5E-1-2: Public Indecency
6-5E-1-3: Obscene Publications And Photographs
6-5E-1-4: Admissions To Obscene Performances
6-5E-1-5: Minors
6-5E-1-6: Exceptions To Provisions
6-5E-1-7: Revocation Of License
6-5E-2: Prostitution And Related Offenses
6-5E-3: Wagering Services
6-5E-1: OBSCENITY:
6-5E-1-1:   DEFINITIONS:
For the purposes of this section
 6-5E-1, the following words shall have the meanings indicated unless their
context clearly requires otherwise:
   DISTRIBUTE: To transfer possession of, whether with or without
consideration.
   EXHIBIT: To show or display, offer or present for inspection or produce in
public so that it may be taken into possession or viewed by persons.
   HARMFUL TO MINORS: That quality of any description or representation, in
whatever form, of nudity, sexual conduct, sexual excitement or sadomasochistic
abuse, when it:
   A.   Predominantly appeals to the prurient, shameful or morbid interest of
minors;
   B.   Is patently offensive to prevailing standards in the adult community as
a whole with respect to what is suitable material for minors; and
   C.   Is utterly without redeeming social importance for minors.
   KNOWINGLY: Having general knowledge of, or reason to know, or a belief or
ground for belief which warrants further inquiry of all of the following:
   A.   The character and content of any material described herein which is
reasonably susceptible to examination by the defendant.
   B.   Being aware of the character of the matter of live conduct.
   C.   The age of the minor; provided, however, that an honest mistake shall
constitute an excuse from liability hereunder if the defendant made a
reasonable bona fide attempt to ascertain the true age of such minor.
   MINOR: Any person under the age of eighteen (18) years.
   NUDITY: The showing of the human male or female genitals, pubic area or
buttocks with less than a full opaque covering, or the showing of the female
breast with less than a fully opaque covering of any portion thereof below the
top of the areola, or the depiction of covered male genitals in a discernibly
turgid state.
   OBSCENE: That quality of any description or representation, in whatever
form, of nudity, sexual conduct, sexual excitement or sadomasochistic abuse:
   A.   When, taken as a whole, to the average person applying contemporary
community standards in a patently offensive way:
   1. Predominantly appeals to the prurient, shameful or morbid interest of
adults or special audiences; and
   2. Is offensive with respect to what is suitable material.
   B.   When, taken as a whole, lacks serious artistic, literary, scientific,
political, educational or other merits.
   PATRON OF A PLACE OF OBSCENITY: Any person who shall patronize, frequent, be
found in, or be an inmate of any premises used for the unlawful purposes set
forth in this section
6-5E-1.
   SADOMASOCHISTIC ABUSE: Flagellation or torture by or upon a person clad in
undergarments, a mask or bizarre costume, or the condition of being fettered,
bound or otherwise physically restrained on the part of one so clothed.
   SEXUAL CONDUCT: Acts of masturbation, excretory functions, homosexuality,
sexual intercourse or physical contact with a person's clothed or unclothed
genitals, pubic area, buttocks or, if such person be a female, breasts, normal
or perverted, actual or simulated.
   SEXUAL EXCITEMENT: The condition of human male or female genitals when in a
state of sexual stimulation or arousal.
   THEATER, CONCERT HALL (Or Other Similar Establishment Which Is Primarily
Devoted To Theatrical Performances): A building, playhouse, room, hall or other
place having permanently affixed seats so arranged that a body of spectators
can have an unobstructed view of the stage, upon which theatrical or vaudeville
performances or similar forms of artistic expression are presented, and where
such performances are not incidental to the promoting of the sale of food,
drink or other merchandise for which a village license for a theater is in full
force and effect, and which performance, when taken as a whole, does not lack
serious, artistic, literary, scientific, political or educational value. (1985
Code § 5-5E-1-1)
6-5E-1-2:   PUBLIC INDECENCY:
   A.   It shall be unlawful for any person to urinate or stool in any place
open to the public view, or to be guilty of any lewd, lascivious or obscene
conduct or language, or to sing any lewd or obscene song, ballad or other words
in any public place or any other place where other persons are present or
indecently to exhibit any animal, as defined in 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes
5/11-20. (1985 Code § 5-5E-1-2; amd. 2016 Code)
   B.   It shall be unlawful for any person to appear in a state of nudity, or
in any indecent or lewd dress or condition in any public place, or in any such
place to make any indecent exposure of his or her person or private parts
thereof or the private parts of another, or to conduct himself or herself in a
lewd or lascivious manner, or for a male to appear in any such place in a dress
not belonging to his sex.
   C.   It shall be unlawful for any person in a commercial establishment,
place of public accommodation or private club to employ or have on his premises
any person who exhibits nudity to his patrons.
   D.   It shall be unlawful for any person to exhibit nudity in any commercial
establishment, place of public accommodation or private club to the patrons
thereof.
   E.   It shall be unlawful for any person, while acting as a waiter, waitress
or entertainer in an establishment which serves food, beverages or food and
beverages including, but not limited to, alcoholic beverages, for consumption
on the premises of such establishment, to:
      1.   Expose his or her genitals, pubic hair, buttocks, natal cleft,
perineum, anal region or pubic hair region; or
      2.   Expose any device, costume or covering which gives the appearance of
or simulates the genitals, pubic hair, buttocks, natal cleft, perineum, anal
region or pubic hair region; or
      3.   Expose any portion of the female breast at or below the areola
thereof.
A person shall be deemed to be a waiter, waitress or entertainer if such person
acts in that capacity without regard to whether or not such person is paid any
compensation by the management of the establishment in which the activity is
performed.
   F.   It shall be unlawful for any person, while participating in any live
act, demonstration or exhibition in any public place, place open to the public,
or place open to public view, to:
      1.   Expose his or her genitals, pubic hair, buttocks, natal cleft,
perineum, anal region or pubic hair region; or
      2.   Expose any device, costume or covering which gives the appearance of
or simulates the genitals, pubic hair, buttocks, natal cleft, perineum, anal
region or pubic hair region; or
      3.   Expose any portion of the female breast at or below the areola
thereof.
   G.   It shall be unlawful for a person to cause, permit, procure, counsel or
assist any person to expose or simulate exposure prohibited in subsections E
and F of this section. (1985 Code § 5-5E-1-2)
6-5E-1-3:   OBSCENE PUBLICATIONS AND PHOTOGRAPHS:
It shall be unlawful for any person knowingly to sell, loan for monetary
consideration, distribute or exhibit:
   A.   Any picture, photograph, drawing, sculpture, motion picture film or
similar visual representation or image of a person or portion of the human body
which depicts nudity, sexual conduct or sadomasochistic abuse and which is
obscene; or
   B.   Any book, pamphlet, magazine, printed matter, however reproduced, or
sound recording which contains any matter enumerated in section
 6-5E-1-1 of this chapter, or explicit and detailed verbal descriptions or
narrative accounts of sexual excitement, sexual conduct or sadomasochistic
abuse and which, taken as a whole, is obscene; or
   C.   Any material which is harmful to minors. (1985 Code § 5-5E-1-3)
6-5E-1-4:   ADMISSIONS TO OBSCENE PERFORMANCES:
   A.   It shall be unlawful for any person knowingly to exhibit for a monetary
consideration or knowingly to sell to any person an admission ticket or pass or
knowingly to admit a person for a monetary consideration to premises whereon is
exhibited a motion picture, show, or live or other presentation which, in whole
or in part, depicts nudity, sexual conduct or sadomasochistic abuse and which
is obscene.
   B.   It shall be unlawful for any person knowingly to admit any person to
premises whereon there is exhibited a motion picture, show, or live or other
presentation which, in whole or in part, depicts nudity, sexual conduct or
sadomasochistic abuse and which is obscene. (1985 Code § 5-5E-1-4)
6-5E-1-5:   MINORS:
It shall be unlawful for any person:
   A.   To knowingly sell or loan for a monetary consideration, distribute or
exhibit to a minor any of the prohibited materials described in section
6-5E-1-3 of this chapter.
   B.   To knowingly for a monetary consideration exhibit, sell, or admit a
minor to a premises whereon the prohibited sales in subsection
6-5E-1-4A of this chapter are performed.
   C.   To knowingly admit a minor to the premises whereon the prohibited acts
in subsection
6-5E-1-4B of this chapter are depicted.
   D.   To knowingly exhibit for, or without monetary consideration, or
knowingly to sell to any person an admission ticket or pass, or knowingly to
admit a person for, or without monetary consideration, to premises whereon
there is exhibited a motion picture, show, or live or other presentation which,
in whole or in part, depicts nudity, sexual conduct or sadomasochistic abuse
and which is harmful to minors.
   E.   Under eighteen (18) years of age to state falsely, either orally or in
writing, that he is not under the age of eighteen (18) years, or to present and
offer to any person any evidence of age and identity which is false or not
actually his own for the purpose of ordering, obtaining, viewing or otherwise
procuring or attempting to procure or view any of the prohibited materials and
unlawful acts set forth in subsections
6-5E-1-2C through F and sections
6-5E-1-3 and
6-5E-1-4 of this chapter.
   F.   Under eighteen (18) years of age to be present on any premises where
any of the unlawful acts described in subsections
6-5E-1-2C through F and sections
6-5E-1-3 and
 6-5E-1-4 of this chapter are being committed.
   G.   In a commercial establishment, place of public accommodation or private
club, to employ or have on his premises a minor who exhibits nudity to his
patrons.
   H.   For any minor to exhibit nudity in any commercial establishment, place
of accommodation or private club to the patrons thereof. (1985 Code § 5-5E-1-5)
6-5E-1-6:   EXCEPTIONS TO PROVISIONS:
   A.   Nothing in sections
 6-5E-1-3 and
6-5E-1-4 of this chapter shall prohibit any public library or any library
operated by an accredited institution of higher education from circulating
material to any person, provided such circulation is in aid of a legitimate
scientific or educational purpose, and it shall be an affirmative defense in
any prosecution for a violation of this section
 6-5E-1 that the act charged was committed in aid of legitimate scientific or
educational purposes.
   B.   Provisions of subsections
6-5E-1-2C to F, inclusive, of this chapter shall not apply to a theater,
concert hall or similar establishment which is primarily devoted to theatrical
performances.
   C.   Nothing in this section shall prohibit any parent from distributing to
his child any of the unlawful materials described in section
 6-5E-1-3 of this chapter. (1985 Code § 5-5E-1-6)
6-5E-1-7:   REVOCATION OF LICENSE:
The license of any person or employee thereof directly involved in violations
of this section
 6-5E-1 may be revoked by the village president. No such license so revoked
shall be reinstated until the lapse of a period of one year after such
revocation. Such revocation may be in addition to any fine imposed. Any action
for revocation shall be in accordance with the provisions of section
4-1-9 of this code. (1985 Code § 5-5E-1-7)
6-5E-2: PROSTITUTION AND RELATED OFFENSES:
   A.   Soliciting For Prostitution: It shall be unlawful for any person to
pursue, solicit or advertise in any manner his or her vocation as a prostitute,
or for any person to advertise the profession of a prostitute, or solicit for a
prostitute.
   B.   House Of Prostitution: It shall be unlawful for any person to keep or
assist in the keeping of a house of ill fame or prostitution or knowingly to
reside therein or knowingly to rent, lease or permit any person to occupy any
house or room owned, leased or controlled by him for this purpose.
   C.   Frequenting A House Of Prostitution: It shall be unlawful for any
person to be a patron of a house of ill fame or prostitution. (1985 Code § 5-
5E-2)
6-5E-3: WAGERING SERVICES:
It shall be unlawful for any person not exempted by subsection
4-2-9D of this code: (1985 Code § 5-5E-3; amd. Ord. 06-16, 9-11-2006)
   A.   To accept, receive or transmit, with or without fee, any wager or bet
on any horserace or sport, which wager or bet is hereafter placed at, delivered
to, or transmitted by wire or phone to any racetrack, place of sport or
bookmaker where wagers or bets are received or placed.
   B.   To contract to accept or receive, deliver or transmit by wire or phone
wagers or bets to any racetrack or place of sport or bookmaker where wagers or
bets are received or placed.
   C.   To keep or maintain any premises for the purpose of accepting,
receiving, delivering or transmitting wagers or bets to any racetrack or place
of sport where wagers or bets are received or placed.
   D.   To use or place a wager or bet with any other person for the purpose of
placing at, delivery to or transmitting by wire or phone to any racetrack,
place of sport or bookmaker, said wager or bet.
   E.   To knowingly lease, let or permit any premises to be used in whole or
in part for any of the unlawful purposes described in this section. (1985 Code
§ 5-5E-3)
CHAPTER 6
MINORS
SECTION:
6-6-1: Curfew
6-6-2: Encouraging Delinquency
6-6-3: Parental And Guardian Responsibility
6-6-4: Endangering The Life Or Health Of A Child
6-6-1: CURFEW:
   A.   Rules And Definitions: For purposes of this section, the following
terms, phrases, words and their derivations shall have the meanings given them
in this subsection. When not inconsistent within the context, words used in the
present tense include the future, words in the plural number include the
singular and words in the singular include the plural. The word "shall" is
always mandatory and not merely directory.
   EMERGENCY: An unforeseen combination of circumstances or the resulting state
that calls for immediate action. The term includes, but is not limited to, a
fire, natural disaster, or automobile accident, or any situation requiring
immediate action to prevent serious injury to persons or property.
   ESTABLISHMENT: Any privately owned place of business operated for a profit
to which the public is invited including, but not limited to, any place of
amusement or entertainment.
   JUVENILE: Any person under seventeen (17) years of age.
   OPERATOR: Any individual, firm, association, partnership, or corporation
operating, managing, or conducting any establishment. The term includes the
members or partners of an association or partnership and the officers of a
corporation.
   PARENT: Any person having legal custody of a juvenile: 1) as a natural or
adoptive parent; 2) as a legal guardian; 3) as a person who stands in loco
parentis; or 4) as a person to whom legal custody has been given by court
order.
   PUBLIC PLACE: Any place to which the public or a substantial group of the
public has access and includes, but is not limited to, streets, common areas,
shopping centers, private businesses, and similar areas that are open to the
use of the public.
   B.   Age And Hour Restrictions: In shall be unlawful for any person under
seventeen (17) to be or remain in or upon a public place within the Village
during the following hours:
      1.   Between eleven o'clock (11:00) P.M. Friday and six o'clock (6:00)
A.M. Saturday.
      2.   Between eleven o'clock (11:00) P.M. Saturday and six o'clock (6:00)
A.M. Sunday.
      3.   Between ten o'clock (10:00) P.M. Sunday to Thursday, inclusive, and
six o'clock (6:00) A.M. on the following day.
   C.   Exceptions And Affirmative Defenses: It shall not be a violation of
this section, and it shall otherwise be an affirmative defense, if a juvenile
is:
      1.   Accompanied by the juvenile's parent, custodian or guardian.
      2.   Accompanied by an adult authorized by a parent of such juvenile to
take said parent's place in accompanying said juvenile for a designated period
of time and for purposes within a specified area.
      3.   When a juvenile is on the sidewalk or property where the juvenile
resides, or on either side of or across the street from the place where the
juvenile resides and the adult owner or resident of that property has given
permission for the juvenile to be there.
      4.   When the juvenile has been married.
      5.   In the case of an operator of an establishment, when the operator
has notified the police that a juvenile was present on the premises of the
establishment during curfew hours and refused to leave.
      6.   Participating in, going to, or returning from:
         a.   Lawful employment;
         b.   A school sanctioned activity;
         c.   An emergency situation, or errand of urgent necessity involving
the protection of persons or property;
         d.   An activity involving the exercise of the juvenile's rights
protected under the first amendment of the United States constitution and
article I, sections 3, 4, and 5 of the Illinois constitution, or both, such as
freedom of speech, religion and the right of assembly; or
         e.   Engaged in the interstate or international travel originating
outside the state of Illinois or originating in the state of Illinois.
   D.   Operator Responsibility: It shall be unlawful for an operator of an
establishment to knowingly permit a juvenile to remain in his/her establishment
in violation of this section. The term "knowingly" includes knowledge that a
reasonable operator should be expected to have concerning the patron of the
establishment. The standard for "knowingly" shall be applied through an
objective test, whether a reasonable person in the operator's position would
have known that the patron was a juvenile in violation of this section.
   E.   Parental Responsibility: It shall be unlawful for a parent of a
juvenile to knowingly permit the juvenile to remain in any village public place
in violation of this section. The term "knowingly" includes knowledge that a
reasonable parent should be expected to have concerning the whereabouts of a
juvenile in his/her custody.
   F.   Duties Of Police Officers:
      1.   It shall be the duties of the police officers upon discovering any
juvenile unattended by an adult to:
         a.   Inquire of such juvenile their age, place of residence and
telephone number.
         b.   Inquire as to why the juvenile is out past curfew.
         c.   Assess whether the activity the juvenile is engaged in is/was
protected under this section.
         d.   Assess whether such an exception or defense is reasonable given
the surrounding circumstances, such as time elapsed from beginning or end of
said activity, allowing the juvenile a reasonable amount of time to go to or
return from such activity without violating this section.
      2.   After the inquiries set out in subsection F1 of this section are
made by the officer, and no exceptions or defenses are applicable, it shall be
the duties of the police officers to promptly notify the parents, guardians, or
custodians of such juvenile that such juvenile has been detained for violations
of the provisions of this section and to report to the police station for the
return of said juvenile to their custody. Whenever it is impractical to do so,
the said juvenile may be returned forthwith to his home or to the person
entitled to his custody.
   G.   Penalty: Any person violating any of the provisions of this section
shall be fined not less than twenty five dollars ($25.00) nor more than five
hundred dollars ($500.00) for each offense. (Ord. 04-09, 8-9-2004)
6-6-2: ENCOURAGING DELINQUENCY:
   A.   Generally: It shall be unlawful for any person, by any act or neglect,
to encourage, aid or cause a child to come within the purview of the juvenile
authorities.
   B.   Driving With Suspended Or Revoked License: It shall be unlawful for any
person, after notice that a driver's license of any child has been suspended or
revoked to permit such child to operate a motor vehicle during the period that
such driver's license is suspended.
   C.   Tobacco Sales: It shall be unlawful for any person to sell or give
away, directly or indirectly, to any person under the age of eighteen (18)
years any cigarettes, tobacco or any compounds of tobacco used in filling up or
making up of a cigarette or to give or sell any cigarette papers to minors.
(1985 Code § 5-6-2)
6-6-3: PARENTAL AND GUARDIAN RESPONSIBILITY:
   A.   Definitions: The following terms shall have the meanings ascribed to
them for the purposes of this section:
   LEGAL GUARDIAN: A person appointed guardian or given custody of a minor by a
circuit court of this state, but does not include a person appointed guardian
or given custody of a minor under the juvenile court act, as amended, in the
state of Illinois 1 .
   MINOR: Any person who has not yet attained the age of nineteen (19).
   B.   Parental And Guardian Responsibility Required: It shall be unlawful for
the parent or legal guardian of an unemancipated minor residing with such
parent or legal guardian to fail to exercise proper parental responsibility by
allowing or permitting said minor to commit any violation of a village
ordinance or state statute concerning vandalism, battery, curfew, disorderly
conduct, fireworks, obscene conduct, indecent exposure, trespass or possession
of alcoholic liquor, cannabis or controlled substances, or any other offense of
wilful or malicious acts to persons or property.
   C.   Violation: A parent or legal guardian shall be presumed to have allowed
or permitted said minor to have committed a violation of a village ordinance or
state statute under all of the following conditions:
      1.   Said minor has been either adjudicated to be in violation of any
ordinance or state statute as described in subsection B of this section; or has
been charged with the violation of any ordinance or state statute as described
in subsection B of this section (except if found to be not guilty); or has
incurred nonjudicial sanctions from any peace officer, police officer or
conservator of the peace resulting from an admission of guilt to an offense of
an ordinance or state statute as described in subsection B of this section; and
      2.   Said parent or legal guardian has received a written notice by
certified mail (return receipt requested) or by personal service in
substantially the following form: (1985 Code § 5-6-3)
            LEGAL NOTICE
TO: (Parents' Names)
FROM: Village of Hodgkins
You are hereby notified that (minor's name)  has been involved with a violation
of an ordinance or State statute concerning vandalism, battery, curfew,
disorderly conduct, fireworks, obscene conduct, indecent exposure, trespass or
possession of alcoholic liquor, cannabis or controlled substance, or any other
offense of wilful or malicious acts to persons or property.
If said minor is again involved with a violation of one of the above type
ordinances or State statutes, you may be found guilty of the offense of
Parental Responsibility. Conviction for said offense can result in a fine of
not less than $25 nor more than $500. You are hereby notified that you must
exercise proper parental responsibility over said minor by controlling his
unlawful conduct.
 
(1985 Code § 5-6-3; amd. 2016 Code)
      3.   Said minor, within two (2) years of the receipt of said notice by
the parent or legal guardian, has been either adjudicated to have committed,
has been charged with the violation (except if found to be not guilty), or has
admitted to having committed any violation of any ordinance or state statute as
described in subsection B of this section.
   D.   Village Policy:
      1.   Supervision: It is the policy of the village to permit the village
prosecutor to use the provisions of the unified code of corrections, as
amended, of the state of Illinois pertaining to supervision in order to further
the ends of justice, restitution and purposes of this section.
      2.   Court Appearance Of Parents: It is the policy of the village that a
parent or legal guardian of a minor be notified and required to appear in court
whenever that minor is charged with a violation of an ordinance or state
statute which requires the minor's appearance in court. To this end, it is
hereby directed that a notice in substantially the following form be sent to
the parents or legal guardians of the minor:
            LEGAL NOTICE
TO: (Parents' Names)
FROM: Village of Hodgkins
You are hereby notified that  (minor's name)  has been charged with an offense
which is a violation of a Village ordinance or State statute and which requires
the appearance of said minor in court. You are further notified that one of the
parents of said minor must appear in court before the case will be tried or be
disposed of.
If you fail to appear, the Village Prosecutor has been directed to have issued
a subpoena to bring you into court. Failure to obey a subpoena can result in
contempt of court, with a fine or imprisonment as the penalty.
 
The Village Prosecutor is hereby directed to have subpoenas issued whenever a
parent or legal guardian of a minor does not appear in court after the first
two (2) times said case has been before the court. (1985 Code § 5-6-3)
 
Notes
1 1. 705 ILCS 405/1-1 et seq.
6-6-4: ENDANGERING THE LIFE OR HEALTH OF A CHILD:
   A.   A person commits endangering the life or health of a child when he or
she knowingly: 1) causes or permits the life or health of a child under the age
of eighteen (18) to be endangered; or 2) causes or permits a child to be placed
in circumstances that endanger the child's life or health. It is not a
violation of this section for a person to relinquish a child in accordance with
the Abandoned Newborn Infant Protection Act.
   B.   A trier of fact may infer that a child six (6) years of age or younger
is unattended if that child is left in a motor vehicle for more than ten (10)
minutes.
   C.   "Unattended" means either: 1) not accompanied by a person fourteen (14)
years of age or older; or 2) if accompanied by a person fourteen (14) years of
age or older, out of sight of that person. (Ord. 17-17, 12-11-2017)
CHAPTER 7
WEAPONS
SECTION:
6-7-1: Identification Card Required
6-7-2: Concealed Weapons
6-7-3: Discharge Of Firearms; Bonfires
6-7-4: Bows And Arrows
6-7-1: IDENTIFICATION CARD REQUIRED:
No person, except one exempt by law, may acquire or possess any firearm, stun
gun, taser or firearm ammunition within the village without having a firearm
owner's identification card previously issued in his name, according to the
laws of the state or this chapter. (1985 Code § 5-7-1; amd. 2016 Code)
6-7-2: CONCEALED WEAPONS:
   A.   No person in the village shall wear or carry concealed about his person
any slingshot, metallic knuckles, bowie knife, dirk, razor, chemical mace or
like substance, or other dangerous or deadly weapons, or display or flourish
any such weapon in a boisterous or threatening manner; provided, that the
provisions of this section shall not be held to apply to any peace officer
while in the discharge of his duty, nor to any person summoned by an officer to
aid him in making any arrest or preserving the peace. (1985 Code § 5-7-2; amd.
2016 Code)
   B.   No person in the village shall wear or conceal about his person a
concealed firearm without full compliance with 430 Illinois Compiled Statutes
66/1 et seq. (2016 Code)
6-7-3: DISCHARGE OF FIREARMS; BONFIRES:
   A.   Prohibited: No person shall hunt and no person shall fire or discharge
within the village any cannon, anvil, gun, pistol, air rifle, or firearm, or
set off, fire or explode any torpedo or firecracker, fireball, rocket, or other
fireworks whatever, or make or kindle any bonfire; provided, the discharge of
firearms, the setting off or exploding of firearms and the making of bonfires
upon national holidays and in the celebration of other public and general
events, or the discharge of blank cartridges by a military company when on
parade and in command of the commanding officer, or the discharge of firearms
by any village officer or other person in the discharge of any legal duty when
the same is done in such manner as not to endanger the safety of any person or
injure any property, nor the discharge of firearms in duly licensed shooting
galleries, shall not be deemed a violation of this section. (1985 Code § 5-7-3)
   B.   Report Required: It shall be unlawful for any person to discharge any
firearm, except at a firing range, without reporting such discharge to the
police department as soon as possible. Any person violating this subsection
shall be fined as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code for each offense. (1985 Code § 5-7-3; amd. 2016 Code)
6-7-4: BOWS AND ARROWS:
Hunting with the use of bows and arrows is hereby prohibited. (1985 Code § 5-7-
3)
CHAPTER 8
CANNABIS AND DRUG PARAPHERNALIA
SECTION:
6-8-1: Definitions
6-8-2: Offenses
6-8-3: Penalty
6-8-1: DEFINITIONS:
All terms and phrases used herein shall have the same meaning as ascribed to
them in the Cannabis Control Act 1  and the Drug Paraphernalia Control Act 2
and amendments thereto; except, should the term "person" or "persons" be
limited therein to a natural person who has attained the age of eighteen (18)
years or more, said limitation is specifically excluded herein, and the term
"person" or "persons" is made applicable to all natural persons. (Ord. 16-13,
9-12-2016)
 
Notes
1 1. 720 ILCS 550/1, et seq.
2 2. 720 ILCS 600/1, et seq.
6-8-2: OFFENSES:
   A.   Offense Of Possession Of Cannabis: A person commits the offense of
possession of cannabis by knowingly possessing ten grams (10.0 g) or less of
any substance containing cannabis unless permitted or authorized to do so
pursuant to the Cannabis Control Act 1 .
   B.   Offense Of Possession Of Drug Paraphernalia: A person commits the
offense of possession of drug paraphernalia by knowingly possessing an item of
drug paraphernalia, as defined by 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 600/2, with
the intent to use it ingesting, inhaling, or otherwise introducing cannabis
into the human body, or in preparing cannabis for that use. This does not apply
to a person legally authorized to possess cannabis under law. (Ord. 16-13, 9-
12-2016)
 
Notes
1 3. 720 ILCS 550/1, et seq.
6-8-3: PENALTY:
   A.   Any person violating this chapter shall be subject to a mandatory fine
of not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than two hundred
dollars ($200.00), plus court costs.
   B.   Proceedings to enforce violations of this chapter may be initiated and
conducted in accordance with and pursuant to the provisions of the Village
ordinances providing for administrative adjudication of Code violations or by
any other means provided by law. (Ord. 16-13, 9-12-2016)
TITLE 7
MOTOR VEHICLES AND TRAFFIC
CHAPTER 1
TRAFFIC CODE
SECTION:
7-1-1: Illinois Vehicle Code Adopted
7-1-2: Procedure For Issuance Of Citations (P Tickets)
7-1-1: ILLINOIS VEHICLE CODE ADOPTED:
In lieu of using any section, or in addition to any section of this chapter,
the officer issuing a citation may issue it by using any of the sections of the
Illinois Vehicle Code, which sections of said Illinois Vehicle Code, 625
Illinois Compiled Statutes, and all amendments made from time to time, are
hereby incorporated by reference as a part of this chapter, and every numbered
section in said Illinois Vehicle Code shall be referred to by letters "H"
prefixing said section number. All citations so issued shall be issued in the
name of the Village of Hodgkins, and referred to in the uniform traffic ticket
or complaint as an ordinance violation. The penalties for traffic violations in
this chapter shall apply to said violations. (1985 Code § 6-1-1; amd. Ord. 95-
2, 2-13-1995)
7-1-2: PROCEDURE FOR ISSUANCE OF CITATIONS (P TICKETS):
   A.   Applicable Sections: Whenever a police officer is authorized to arrest
a person without a warrant because of a violation of any section or provision
of this Code in respect to any of the following sections which shall include
the following sections from the Illinois Vehicle Code: (Ord. 92-8, 4-13-1992)

Said police officer may, in lieu of the filing of a complaint in court, in the
first instance, issue to such alleged violator, a citation:
      1.   Advising said person that he has violated a specific ordinance;
      2.   Requesting him to make payment in the amount applicable to said
alleged violation as set forth above as settlement of said violation claim; and
      3.   Informing him that, upon failure to so settle, a complaint will be
filed in the Circuit Court of Cook County charging him with such violation.
   B.   Settlement:
      1.   Pursuant to said citation, the person so accused of said violation
may settle and compromise the violation claim in respect to such Code violation
by paying to the Village the applicable amount as shown in the schedule set
forth as the settlement amount in subsection A of this section within a period
of fifteen (15) days of the time said alleged offense was committed. (Ord. 92-
8, 4-13-1992)
      2.   Such payment shall be made in accordance with the instructions
contained in the aforesaid citation, at the Office of the Village Comptroller
who shall issue a receipt for the money so received and promptly remit said
amount to the Village accounts to be credited to the proper Municipal fund.
(Ord. 92-8, 4-13-1992; amd. 2016 Code)
   C.   Final Notice; Penalty: In the event that the person to whom said
citation is issued fails to settle and pay said violation within the time
specified in the citation, a final notice shall be mailed to him. When, in
fact, the final notice has been mailed, the violation may then be settled and
compromised by paying two (2) times the amount set forth in the schedule in
subsection A of this section within the time specified in the final notice.
   D.   Issuance Of Complaint: In the event that the person to whom the
citation is issued fails to settle and pay said violation claim within the time
specified in the final notice (if one is served or mailed to him), then the
police officer is authorized to cause the citation (notice to appear P ticket)
to be served upon said alleged violator and is authorized to file the same as a
complaint in the Circuit Court of Cook County and prosecute the same. The
officer, as an alternative, may file a formal complaint in the Circuit Court of
Cook County in lieu of the citation. (Ord. 92-8, 4-13-1992)
   E.   Court Penalty; Settlement Before Court Date: In the event that payment
is not made within the time prescribed in the final notice, and the citation or
complaint is filed in the Circuit Court, payment of any fine and costs shall be
in such amounts as may be determined and established by the circuit court, but
not to exceed the sum as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code for any one violation; provided, that the offenses may be
settled and compromised for the amount specified in the notice to appear at
least three (3) working days before the court date. Such amount shall be three
(3) times the amount set forth in subsection A of this section. (Ord. 92-8, 4-
13-1992; amd. 2016 Code)
   F.   Correction Of Violation: The payment of an amount as settlement herein
will not excuse the securing of and the payment of a license fee provided in
this code or correction of the violation.
   G.   Parking Violation:
      1.   The fact that an automobile or motor vehicle which is illegally
operated or parked is registered with the secretary of state in the name of
said alleged violator; or in the alternative, in the event that a vehicle
sticker issued by the village has been issued in the name of and to said
alleged violator, shall be proof that said alleged violator was in control of
or was the operator of the automobile or motor vehicle at the time of such
alleged violation.
      2.   The commercial lessor of any vehicle, whether or not the registered
owner, shall be responsible for such parking violation and subject to the
penalty therefor. (Ord. 92-8, 4-13-1992)
CHAPTER 2
VEHICLE LICENSES
SECTION:
7-2-1: Definition
7-2-2: State Licenses Required
7-2-3: Village Licenses Required
7-2-4: Application For License; Term
7-2-5: License Fees
7-2-6: License Tags
7-2-7: Sale Or Transfer Of Vehicle
7-2-8: Exemptions
7-2-9: Unlicensed Motorized Devices
7-2-1: DEFINITION:
The term "motor vehicle", when used in this chapter, shall mean every self-
propelled device in, upon or by which any person or property is or may be
transported or drawn upon a highway or in the village, except devices moved by
human power. (1985 Code § 6-2-1)
7-2-2: STATE LICENSES REQUIRED:
   A.   Vehicle License: It shall be unlawful for any motor vehicle to be
driven in or upon or used in or upon any street, parkway, sidewalk, public way,
public alley, public property, semipublic property, shopping center, park or
school grounds without having a license issued to said vehicle by the state. It
shall be unlawful for any person to have in his possession a motor vehicle for
use which cannot be licensed by the secretary of state. The possession of such
vehicle by any person is hereby declared to be a nuisance. (1985 Code § 6-2-2;
amd. 2016 Code)
   B.   Driver's Licenses: It shall be unlawful for any person to drive a motor
vehicle in or upon or use any highway, street, parkway, sidewalk, public way,
public alley, public property, semipublic property, park, public or parochial
school grounds, shopping center or drainage basin without having a valid
driver's license issued thereto. (1985 Code § 6-2-2)
7-2-3: VILLAGE LICENSES REQUIRED:
   A.   No person having his residence in the village shall use, or cause to be
used, any motor vehicle or vehicle in the transportation of persons or property
or the conveyance of loads in the village without first having obtained a
license as provided herein.
   B.   No firm or corporation having its residence in the village or having
its principal office or place of business in the village shall use, or cause or
permit any of its agents or employees to use, any motor vehicle or vehicle in
the transportation of persons or property or conveyance of loads in the village
without first having obtained a vehicle license as provided herein.
   C.   No person, firm or corporation owning a vehicle, which vehicle is
housed, located or has its situs or base in the village, shall use, or cause or
permit any of his or its agents or employees to use, any such motor vehicle or
vehicle in the transportation of persons or property or the conveyance of loads
in the village without first having obtained a vehicle license as provided
herein.
   D.   It shall be unlawful for any person to use any motor vehicle or vehicle
in the village unless such motor vehicle or vehicle is licensed as provided
herein. (1985 Code § 6-2-3)
7-2-4: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE; TERM:
   A.   Any person desiring a license for any vehicle shall file an application
therefor with the village clerk upon a form provided thereby, setting forth the
name and address of the applicant, the description of the vehicle and such
information as may be prescribed. Upon demand by the village clerk, the
applicant shall display the state identification card for each vehicle at the
time of application. Such license shall issue upon the payment by the applicant
of a license fee as determined by the village board of trustees to the village
clerk, and shall authorize the use of such vehicle within the village under the
expiration of such license. (1985 Code § 6-2-4; amd. 2016 Code)
   B.   All licenses issued under the provisions of this chapter shall be for a
year and shall begin June 1 and expire May 31 following their issuance. (1985
Code § 6-2-4; amd. Ord. 05-17, 6-13-2005; 2016 Code)
7-2-5: LICENSE FEES:
   A.   The license fee for each motor vehicle or vehicle to be paid annually
to the village clerk shall be as determined by the village board of trustees.
   B.   If such vehicle has been purchased or lawfully acquired by the
applicant on or after December 1 of any current year, the fee to be paid shall
be a sum equal to one-half (1/2) of the annual license fee, as a license fee
for the balance of such year. Before any applicant shall be entitled to a
prorated license as provided in this subsection, the said applicant shall
furnish an affidavit, in form satisfactory to the village clerk, stating that
the vehicle for which the license is applied was purchased or otherwise
obtained by the applicant on or after December 1 of the current year, and shall
exhibit to the village clerk the bill of sale covering the vehicle for which
license is sought.
   C.   Any vehicle required to have a license by section
 7-2-3 of this chapter on September 30, which does not have said license
affixed thereto by twelve o'clock (12:00) midnight on said date of the license
year, or does not have a vehicle license affixed thereto in the time provided
by this chapter, shall pay double the amount as determined by the village board
of trustees for the current required vehicle license. (1985 Code § 6-2-5; amd.
2016 Code)
7-2-6: LICENSE TAGS:
   A.   Upon the issuance of said license, the village clerk shall deliver to
the applicant a gummed tag, decal or sticker upon which shall appear the word
"HODGKINS" and a number identical with the number of such license and the year
for which such license is issued, and it shall be the duty of the applicant to
affix such gummed tag, decal or sticker upon the windshield of the motor
vehicle, or if there is no windshield, then in a conspicuous place upon said
motor vehicle where it can be readily seen. It shall be unlawful for any motor
vehicle, although duly licensed, to be used in the village unless such tag or
sticker is attached thereto.
   B.   No resident owner shall be required to display on his vehicle the plate
or tax or license number issued by a city, village or incorporated town of his
residence if the vehicle is displaying the plate or tax or license number
issued by the place wherein the vehicle has its situs or base. (1985 Code § 6-
2-6)
7-2-7: SALE OR TRANSFER OF VEHICLE:
Immediately upon the sale or transfer of any motor vehicle which has been
therefor licensed as provided herein, prior to its date of such sale or
transfer, the vendor or transferer shall remove the license tag, decal or
sticker from the vehicle so sold or transferred, and the license so issued for
such vehicle shall cease to apply to said vehicle from such date. Upon a
showing to the village clerk that said tag, decal or sticker has been so
removed from such sold or transferred vehicle, the village clerk may issue a
new tag bearing a new number, which shall apply to and be assigned to any other
vehicle of the same class owned by said vendor or transferer. Except as herein
provided, no tag, decal or sticker issued for or assigned to any vehicle shall
ever be used for, or attached to, or upon another and different vehicle. (1985
Code § 6-2-7; amd. 2016 Code)
7-2-8: EXEMPTIONS:
   A.   Any resident who shall be declared by said person's physician to be a
person with disabilities for at least one year shall be exempt from the payment
of a license fee required in section
 7-2-5 of this chapter. The village clerk or comptroller shall require proof of
said disability in the form of a letter signed by the physician attending said
person with disabilities.
   B.   No village resident shall pay a license fee for a noncommercial
vehicle. (1985 Code § 6-2-8; amd. 2016 Code)
7-2-9: UNLICENSED MOTORIZED DEVICES:
   A.   Definitions: For purposes of this section, the following terms shall be
defined as provided in this subsection:
   PUBLIC PROPERTY: Any public street, public sidewalk, public alley, public
park or any other property owned or controlled by the village of Hodgkins, the
Hodgkins park district, a public or private high school or grammar school or
any other property owned or controlled by a unit of local government located
within the village of Hodgkins.
   UNLICENSED MOTORIZED DEVICE: Any motorized device or vehicle not bearing the
proper registration plates from the Illinois secretary of state or incapable of
being registered by the Illinois secretary of state under the provisions of the
Illinois vehicle code, and shall include, but is not limited to, motor
scooters, go-carts, golf carts, mopeds, minibikes or motorbikes.
   B.   Prohibited On Public Property; Exemptions: It shall be unlawful for any
person to operate an unlicensed motorized device on any public property. This
section shall not apply to automobiles, "motorized wheelchairs" (as defined by
the Illinois vehicle code) and any motorized device or vehicle incapable of
reaching a speed in excess of three (3) miles per hour.
   C.   Impoundment Procedure; Prima Facie Proof: Whenever a police officer has
probable cause to believe that a violation of this section has occurred, he is
hereby authorized to seize and impound the unlicensed motorized device. The
failure to display the proper registration from the Illinois secretary of state
is prima facie proof that the instrumentality constitutes an unlicensed
motorized device.
   D.   Hearings:
      1.   Preliminary Hearing: The owner of an unlicensed motorized device (or
any interested party) which has been impounded pursuant to this section shall
have the right to a preliminary hearing to determine whether the seizure and
impoundment was erroneous. The preliminary hearing shall be requested in
writing to the chief of police, or his designee, within forty eight (48) hours
of seizure. The hearing shall be conducted within forty eight (48) hours of
receipt of a written demand for the hearing by the chief of police or his
designee. Failure to request or attend a scheduled hearing within forty eight
(48) hours of the seizure shall be deemed a waiver of the right to a
preliminary hearing. If the hearing officer determines, by a preponderance of
the evidence, that the provisions of this section have been violated, he shall
order that the unlicensed motorized device remain impounded until a bond in the
amount of one hundred dollars ($100.00) is posted with the village police
department. If the hearing officer determines that the provisions of this
section were not violated, the item seized shall be returned to the owner.
      2.   Final Hearing: A hearing shall be conducted pursuant to the
provisions of this section. The hearing shall be held within forty five (45)
days of the seizure. The hearing officer shall be authorized to release the
seized unlicensed motorized device upon payment of a fine and an additional
storage charge in the amount of five dollars ($5.00) per day. If a bond has
been posted, it shall be applied toward the fine and storage charges. If the
hearing officer determines that the provisions of this section have not been
violated, the seized item shall be returned to its owner and any posted bond
refunded. Any unlicensed motorized device which remains unclaimed for a period
in excess of one year shall be presumed abandoned and may be destroyed. (Ord.
02-08, 10-22-2002)
CHAPTER 3
GENERAL TRAFFIC PROVISIONS
SECTION:
7-3-1: Applicability Of Provisions
7-3-2: Obedience To Police
7-3-3: Signs Posted
7-3-4: Restrictions On Driving
7-3-5: Obstructing Crossings
7-3-6: Vehicle Weight Limitations
7-3-7: Oversize And Overweight Vehicles
7-3-8: Vehicle Operation Restrictions
7-3-9: Skitching
7-3-10: Soliciting Rides Or Business (Repl. by Ord. 21-09, 10-11-2021)
7-3-1: APPLICABILITY OF PROVISIONS:
Every person riding or driving any vehicle or riding a bicycle or an animal or
driving any animal drawing a vehicle upon a roadway shall be subject to the
provisions of this title applicable to a driver of a vehicle except those
provisions which by their nature can have no application. (1985 Code § 6-3-1)
7-3-2: OBEDIENCE TO POLICE:
Members of the police department are hereby authorized to direct all traffic in
accordance with the provisions of this title or, in emergencies, as public
safety or convenience may require, and it shall be unlawful for any person to
fail or refuse to comply with any lawful order, signal or direction of a police
officer. Except in case of emergency, it shall be unlawful for any person not
authorized by the chief of police to direct or attempt to direct traffic. (1985
Code § 6-3-2)
7-3-3: SIGNS POSTED:
It shall be the duty of the chief of police to determine and designate the
character of all official signs which purport to direct the movement of
traffic, and he shall post adequate signs, where such signs may be necessary,
for the effective enforcement of this title. All signs shall conform to the
state sign manual. (1985 Code § 6-3-3)
7-3-4: RESTRICTIONS ON DRIVING:
   A.   Driving In Certain Zoned Areas: It shall be unlawful for any motor
vehicle to be driven or for a person to drive the same upon any public or
private property not properly zoned for the use to which said vehicle is being
put or which is not incident to the zoned use, or legally recognized as one of
the uses permitted on said property.
   B.   Driving In Certain Places: It shall be unlawful for any vehicle to be
driven upon any public property, semipublic property, park or school property,
except in those parts of said property improved as driveways and recognized
portions of the premises devoted for ingress and egress for motor vehicles or
used for parking incident to the principal uses permitted on said property.
   C.   Driving On Sidewalks, Lawns, Etc.: No person shall drive any vehicle on
or across any sidewalk, boulevard, lawn, parkway or property where there is no
regular approach or driveway for the use of vehicular traffic.
   D.   Emerging From Alley, Driveway Or Building: The driver of a vehicle
within the village emerging from an alley, driveway or building shall stop such
vehicle immediately prior to driving onto a sidewalk or into the sidewalk area
extending across an alley or private driveway. (1985 Code § 6-3-4)
7-3-5: OBSTRUCTING CROSSINGS:
No person shall stop any car or other vehicle for pleasure or burden on any of
the crossings of the streets or alleys of the village so as to inconvenience
persons crossing the same, or shall in any manner obstruct any crossings except
so far as may be necessary in passing over or across the same. (1985 Code § 6-
3-5; amd. 2016 Code)
7-3-6: VEHICLE WEIGHT LIMITATIONS:
   A.   Weight Limitations On Certain Streets:
      1.   It shall be unlawful to stand, park, drive or move a vehicle if the
maximum gross weight of the vehicle, including the load, exceeds eight thousand
(8,000) pounds on the following streets:
Chester Street.
Cobb Street.
Conrad Avenue.
Kane Avenue.
Kimball Avenue.
Lenzi Avenue (Center Avenue) from U.S. Route No. 66 (Joliet Road) to a point
495 feet north of the south line of Quarry Road.
Lyons Street.
Power Line Road.
Weeping Willow Road.
Wenz Avenue.
      2.   It shall be unlawful to stand, park, drive or move a vehicle of the
second division, as defined in the Illinois vehicle code, bearing state of
Illinois C to VDB class license plates, on the following streets:
Lenzi Avenue (Center Avenue) from U.S. Route No. 66 (Joliet Road) to a point
495 feet north of the south line of Quarry Road.
      3.   Adequate signs giving notice of the limitations and prohibitions of
this subsection A shall be posted. (1985 Code § 6-3-6; amd. Ord. 98-21, 11-9-
1998)
   B.   Truck Routes: Truck routes are streets which use is limited to state or
county weight and use restrictions. The following streets are designated as
truck routes:
East Avenue.
Joliet Road.
LaGrange Road.
67th Street.
The director of the department of public works shall place on the street name
signs of the streets designated as a truck route, the words "Truck Route".
   C.   No Left Turn Permitted: There shall be no left turns permitted off of
Power Line Road onto 67th Street. (1985 Code § 6-3-6)
7-3-7: OVERSIZE AND OVERWEIGHT VEHICLES:
   A.   Permit Required; Size And Weight Limits; Routes Designated:
      1.   Permit Required; Size And Weight Limits:
         a.   A permit shall be required for the movement of any vehicle or
combination of vehicles which exceeds the following limits:
            (1)   Weight: More than seventy three thousand two hundred eighty
(73,280) pounds; except, that vehicles weighing up to eighty thousand (80,000)
pounds are permitted access to locations within one mile of both I-55 and I-294
within the village limits and upon roadways maintained by the state of
Illinois, which are LaGrange Road (Route 45) and Joliet Road (Route 66), in
accordance with exceptions granted by state law.
            (2)   Length: More than sixty feet (60').
            (3)   Width: More than eight feet six inches (8'6").
            (4)   Height: More than thirteen feet six inches (13'6").
         b.   Maximum practical weights for which permits will be issued are as
follows:
            (1)   Six (6) axle tractor semitrailer combination: One hundred
twenty thousand (120,000) pounds' gross; forty eight thousand (48,000) pounds
on drive tandems; sixty thousand (60,000) pounds on semitrailer three (3) axle
tandem;
            (2)   Five (5) axle tractor semitrailer combination: One hundred
thousand (100,000) pounds' gross; maximum of forty eight thousand (48,000)
pounds on either tandem;
            (3)   Four (4) or more axle vehicle (axle spacing 23 feet or more):
Seventy six thousand (76,000) pounds' gross; maximum of thirty four thousand
(34,000) pounds on one tandem and forty four thousand (44,000) pounds on the
other;
            (4)   Three (3) or more axle vehicle (axle spacing 18 feet or
more): Maximum sixty eight thousand (68,000) pounds' gross; twenty thousand
(20,000) pounds on one axle and forty eight thousand (48,000) pounds on the
tandem;
            (5)   Two (2) axle vehicle: Maximum forty eight thousand (48,000)
pounds; neither axle exceeds twenty five thousand (25,000) pounds.
Practical maximum weights will be adhered to; except, that overweight moves
exceeding the practical maximum weights or on nonstandard vehicles or with
nonstandard axle configuration may be authorized if allowable pavement and
bridge stresses are not exceeded. These moves normally require additional time
for analysis.
      2.   Routes Designated:
         a.   The following roads are designated permit routes:
River Road.
Santa Fe Drive south of 67th Street and east of I-294.
         b.   The following roads are designated local roads with weight limits
of up to eighty thousand (80,000) pounds' gross, twenty thousand (20,000)
pounds on a single axle, and thirty four thousand (34,000) pounds on a tandem
axle. The bridge formula found in 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/15-111(a)
shall apply:
Catherine Ann Drive east of East Avenue.
Lenzi Avenue south of Joliet Road.
         c.   Any person, corporation, partnership, sole proprietorship or
organization moving an oversized load upon 67th Street between LaGrange Road
(Route 45) and East Avenue with a permit issued by the Illinois department of
transportation shall also obtain a village permit via telephone (708-352-4623)
or by sending a facsimile (708-579-6712) of the permit, for a fee of one
hundred dollars ($100.00). The permit must be in writing and carried in the
vehicle to which it refers.
   B.   Application For Permit: Application for a permit to move on village
streets and bridges an overweight and/or overdimension vehicle, or combination
of vehicles, with a load which has been reasonably disassembled must be made to
the village chief of police, and the following information shall be included:
      1.   Name, address and phone number of the applicant and the applicant's
business name, address and telephone number;
      2.   Whether the permit is requested for a single trip or for limited
continuous operation;
      3.   Whether the applicant is an authorized carrier under the Illinois
motor carrier of property law, and if so, the registration, certificate or
permit number issued by the Illinois commerce commission;
      4.   The Illinois department of transportation's registration number or
classification, and a specific description of the vehicle or vehicles and the
load;
      5.   The routing, including point of origin and destination; and
      6.   Whether the vehicle or loads are being transported for hire.
   C.   Permit Fees:
      1.   Fees for permits shall be assessed as follows:
      STATE PERMITTED OVERWEIGHT VEHICLES

      OVERDIMENSION VEHICLES
