      2.   If vehicles are both overweight and overdimension, applicable fees
for both must be paid to obtain a permit.
   D.   Bond And Deposit Requirements:
      1.   Bond: Any person, corporation, partnership, sole proprietorship or
organization may seek permits to move overweight/overdimension vehicles on
village streets if there is on deposit with the village a cash bond in the
amount of two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00) in a certified or
cashier's check made in favor of the village, or in lieu of a cash bond, a
license/permit bond in the amount of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) to cover
any damages to village streets or property. If a portion of the bond must be
used to pay for such damage, no further applications for permits under this
section will be considered until the full amount is replenished. Bond will be
returned within ten (10) days upon request if no permits are outstanding, but
no further permit shall be issued without redeposit of such bond.
      2.   Deposit: Any person, corporation, partnership, sole proprietorship
or organization may deposit with the village any amount which it considers
sufficient upon which a draw may be made for permit fees. Applicants
maintaining sufficient funds in such a deposit account and who have provided
the cash bond or license/permit bond required in subsection C2 of this section
may be issued permits by telephone by the village chief of police or his
designee, and the fee for such permit shall be withdrawn from the deposit
account. In no instance shall telephone permits be issued if an amount
insufficient to cover the cost of the required permit remains in the account.
   E.   Conditions Of Permit:
      1.   Permits for single trip movements shall be issued as follows:
         a.   Permits for single trip movements are issued for one-way
movement. These permits are valid for five (5) days from the date of issuance;
         b.   Unless stated otherwise on the permit, permit movements may be
made only from one-half (1/2) hour before sunrise to one-half (1/2) hour after
sunset on weekdays and from one-half (1/2) hour before sunrise to twelve
o'clock (12:00) noon on Saturday, central time.
      2.   Permits for round trips shall be issued as follows:
         a.   The same object is to be moved in both directions.
         b.   The same route is to be traveled in the reverse direction.
         c.   Round trip permits over a circular or roundabout route will not
routinely be issued. A single trip permit will not be revised to include "round
trip" after a move has been undertaken. Round trip permits are subject to the
restrictions contained in subsection A1b of this section; except, that such
permits are valid for a period of ten (10) working days and one round trip move
from the date of issuance.
   F.   Escort Required: Civilian and/or police escort of overweight and/or
overdimension vehicles as described in subsection C1 of this section shall be
required as follows:
      1.   Class 3A vehicles may require a civilian escort vehicle. The driver
of a civilian escort vehicle must be in radio contact with the driver of a
permit vehicle.
      2.   Class 4A vehicles may require a civilian escort and may require a
village police department escort. The driver of the civilian escort vehicle
must be in radio contact with the driver of the permit vehicle.
      3.   Class 2B vehicles require one civilian escort vehicle. The driver of
the civilian escort vehicle must be in radio contact with the driver of the
permit vehicle.
      4.   Class 3B vehicles require one civilian escort vehicle. The driver of
the civilian escort vehicle must be in radio contact with the driver of the
permit vehicle. A village police department vehicle escort may also be
required.
   G.   Liability For Damage: Any person driving any vehicle, object or
contrivance upon any street or bridge is liable for all damage which the
street, bridge or village owned appurtenance thereto may sustain as a result of
any illegal operation, driving or moving of such vehicle, object or contrivance
authorized by a special permit issued as provided in this section. The measure
of liability is the cost of repairing a facility partially damaged or the
replacement cost of a facility damaged beyond repair, together with all other
expenses incurred by the village in providing a temporary detour, including a
temporary street or bridge, to serve the needs of traffic during the period of
repair or replacement of the street or bridge. Whenever such driver is not the
owner of such vehicle, object or contrivance, but is so operating, driving or
moving the same with the express or implied permission of such owner, then the
owner is liable to the extent provided in this section. Recovery may be had in
a civil action brought by the village.
   H.   Application Of Provisions; Exemptions:
      1.   This section applies only to permits for the movement of overweight
and/or overdimension vehicles on village streets. Appropriate permits must be
obtained for movement of these vehicles on county or state highways which are
located within the village.
      2.   This section shall not apply to emergency vehicles including, but
not limited to, firetrucks, ambulances and utility servicing trucks.
   I.   Penalty: All overweight violations shall be fined in accordance with
the schedule set forth in 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/15-113 and all
applicable circuit court fees. (Ord. 98-21, 11-9-1998)
7-3-8: VEHICLE OPERATION RESTRICTIONS:
   A.   Squealing Tires: It shall be unlawful to operate a vehicle in such a
manner so as to cause or produce unnecessary or loud or unusual noises by tire
friction upon rapid turning or weaving or by spinning of the wheels from a
standing or slow moving position produced by sudden unnecessary motor
acceleration.
   B.   Negligent Driving: It shall be unlawful for any person to operate any
vehicle upon a public way or street negligently, heedlessly and without due
caution or in a manner as to endanger or be likely to endanger any person or
property. (1985 Code § 6-3-7)
   C.   Engine Braking:
      1.   Nuisance Declared: Causing unnecessary noise upon the public way by
the use of any engine braking system is hereby declared to be a nuisance
subject to abatement as such.
      2.   Prohibited Generally; Exceptions: No person shall operate any engine
braking system ("jake brakes") on streets designated by ordinance and properly
signposted, except in the case of emergency.
      3.   Prohibited Streets: The operation of any engine braking system
("jake braking") is prohibited, except in the case of emergency, on the
following streets within the village jurisdiction:
Southbound I-55 ramp to northbound Route 45 (LaGrange Road).
Route 45 (LaGrange Road) between 75th Street and Joliet Road.
      4.   Signs Posted: The village public works department is hereby directed
to post signs in conformance with this subsection C and all applicable state
and federal regulations. (Ord. 04-10, 8-9-2004)
      5.   Penalty: Any person violating any of the provisions of this
subsection C shall be fined not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than
seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each offense. (Ord. 04-10, 8-9-2004;
amd. 2016 Code)
7-3-9: SKITCHING:
It shall be unlawful for any person on the streets, public property or parking
lots of the village to hitch a ride upon any other motor vehicle or snowmobile
by flipping or holding thereon, or attaching any ski, sled, bicycle,
skateboard, board, vehicle or motor vehicle to another motor vehicle or
snowmobile while the same is in motion, either by hand, rope or other means
(commonly called "skitching"). It shall be unlawful for any person driving a
motor vehicle or snowmobile to permit any of the unlawful acts mentioned in
this section. The prohibition against skitching shall not be construed to
include the tow of disabled vehicles. (1985 Code § 6-3-8)
7-3-10: SOLICITING RIDES OR BUSINESS:
(Repl. by Ord. 21-09, 10-11-2021)
CHAPTER 4
SPEED RESTRICTIONS
SECTION:
7-4-1: State Speed Laws Applicable
7-4-2: General Speed Restrictions
7-4-3: Minimum Speed Regulation
7-4-4: Speed Limits On Specific Streets And Areas
7-4-5: Emergency Vehicles Exempt
7-4-1: STATE SPEED LAWS APPLICABLE:
The state traffic laws regulating the speed of vehicles shall be applicable
upon all streets within the village except as this chapter, as authorized by
state law, hereby declares and determines upon the basis of engineering and
traffic investigation that certain speed regulations shall be applicable upon
specified streets or in certain areas, in which event, it shall be prima facie
unlawful for any person to drive a vehicle at a speed in excess of any speed so
declared in this chapter when signs are in place giving notice thereof. (1985
Code § 6-4-1)
7-4-2: GENERAL SPEED RESTRICTIONS:
   A.   No person shall drive a vehicle upon any public highway in the village
at a speed greater than is reasonable and proper having regard to the traffic
and the use of the way or so to endanger life or limb or injure the property of
any person. If the rate of speed of any motor vehicle operated upon any public
street or highway in the village where the same passes through a business
district, a residence district or a suburban district exceeds twenty (20) miles
an hour; or the rate of speed of any vehicle exceeds fifteen (15) miles per
hour in a public alley; or if the rate of speed of any vehicle exceeds the
posted speed limit on highways under the jurisdiction of Cook County or the
state, unless such speed is decreased by subsection
7-4-4A of this chapter, or exceeds the rate prescribed on the roads in section
 7-4-1 of this chapter, such rates of speed shall be prima facie evidence that
the person operating such motor vehicle is running at a rate of speed greater
than is reasonable and proper having regard to the traffic and use of the way
or so as to endanger the life or limb or injure the property of any person. The
speed of all vehicles shall always be reasonable and safe and be governed by
the general requirements of this section.
   B.   The fact that the speed of a vehicle is lower than the prima facie
limits set out in subsection A of this section shall not relieve the driver
from the duty to decrease speed when approaching and crossing an intersection,
when approaching and going around a curve, when approaching a hillcrest, when
traveling upon any narrow or winding roadway, or when special hazard exists
with respect to pedestrians or other traffic or by reason of weather or highway
conditions, and speed shall be decreased as may be necessary to avoid colliding
with any person or vehicle, or on entering the highway in compliance with legal
requirements and the duty of all persons to use due care. (1985 Code § 6-4-2)
7-4-3: MINIMUM SPEED REGULATION:
No person shall drive a motor vehicle at such a slow speed as to impede or
block the normal and reasonable movement of traffic except when reduced speed
is necessary for safe operation of his vehicle or in compliance with law. (1985
Code § 6-4-3)
7-4-4: SPEED LIMITS ON SPECIFIC STREETS AND AREAS:
   A.   Areas Outside Business And Residence Districts: It is hereby
determined, upon the basis of an engineering and traffic investigation, that
the speed permitted by state and county law outside of business and residence
districts as applicable upon the following streets is greater than is
reasonable or safe under the conditions found to exist upon such streets, and
it is hereby declared that the prima facie speed limit shall be thirty five
(35) miles per hour as herein set forth on those streets or parts of streets
herein designated at the times herein specified when signs are erected giving
notice thereof:
East Avenue north of 67th Street, at all times.
   B.   School Zones: No person shall drive a motor vehicle at a speed in
excess of twenty (20) miles per hour while passing a school zone or while
traveling upon any public thoroughfare on or across which children pass going
to and from school during school days when schoolchildren are present. This
subsection shall not be applicable unless appropriate signs are posted upon
streets and highways. Such signs shall give proper due warning that a school
zone is being approached and shall indicate the school zone and the maximum
speed limit in effect during school days when schoolchildren are present. (1985
Code § 6-4-4)
7-4-5: EMERGENCY VEHICLES EXEMPT:
The prima facie speed limitations set forth in this chapter shall not apply to
authorized emergency vehicles when responding to emergency calls and the
drivers thereof sound audible signal by bell, siren or exhaust whistle. This
section shall not relieve the driver of an authorized emergency vehicle from
the duty to drive with due regard for the safety of all persons using the
street, nor shall it protect the driver of any such vehicle from the
consequences of a reckless disregard of the safety of others. (1985 Code § 6-4-
5)
CHAPTER 5
STOPPING, STANDING OR PARKING
SECTION:
7-5-1: Authority To Regulate Parking
7-5-2: Stopping, Standing And Parking Prohibited In Specified Places
7-5-3: Parking Prohibited On Certain Streets
7-5-4: Snow Routes
7-5-5: Stopping And Parking Prohibitions And Restrictions
7-5-6: Stopping Or Parking Close To Curb
7-5-7: Lights On Parked Vehicles
7-5-8: Removal Of Improperly Parked Vehicles
7-5-9: Liability Of Registered Owner
7-5-1: AUTHORITY TO REGULATE PARKING:
   A.   The village shall have authority to prohibit parking or to prescribe
time limits for parking on any street under the control and jurisdiction of the
state or village or for the maintenance of which the state, county or village
is responsible, in such manner as to promote public convenience and safety and
so as to facilitate traffic. Any such regulations adopted by the state, county
or village regarding parking upon any specific street or streets shall become
effective on and after the date of the erecting of appropriate signs indicating
such regulations. Any such signs may be erected either by the state or the
county or by the village through its chief of police. All such signs now
erected and in place are hereby determined to be parking signs which must be
obeyed.
   B.   This section shall not apply to the driver of any vehicle which is
disabled on the paved or improved or main traveled portion of a highway or
street in such manner and to such extent that it is impossible to avoid
stopping and temporarily leaving such disabled vehicle in such position. (1985
Code § 6-5-1)
7-5-2: STOPPING, STANDING AND PARKING PROHIBITED IN SPECIFIED PLACES:
   A.   Except when necessary to avoid conflict with other traffic, or in
compliance with law or the directions of a police officer or official traffic
control device, no person shall:
      1.   Stop, stand or park a vehicle:
         a.   On the roadway side of any vehicle stopped or parked at the edge
or curb of a street.
         b.   On a sidewalk.
         c.   Within an intersection.
         d.   On a crosswalk.
         e.   Between a safety zone and the adjacent curb or within thirty feet
(30') of points on the curb immediately opposite the ends of a safety zone,
unless a different length is indicated by signs or markings.
         f.   Alongside or opposite any street excavation or obstruction when
stopping, standing or parking would obstruct traffic.
         g.   Upon any bridge or other elevated structure upon a highway or
within a highway tunnel.
         h.   On any railroad tracks. A violation of this subsection shall
result in a mandatory fine of five hundred dollars ($500.00) or fifty (50)
hours of community service.
         i.   On any controlled access highway.
         j.   In the area between roadways of a divided highway, including
crossovers.
         k.   In a public parking area if the vehicle does not display a
current annual registration sticker or current temporary permit pending
registration.
         l.   At any place where official signs prohibit stopping.
      2.   Stand or park a vehicle, whether occupied or not, except momentarily
to pick up or discharge passengers:
         a.   In front of a public or private driveway.
         b.   Within fifteen feet (15') of a fire hydrant.
         c.   Within twenty feet (20') of a crosswalk at an intersection.
         d.   Within thirty feet (30') upon the approach to any flashing
signal, stop sign, yield sign, or traffic control signal located at the side of
a roadway.
         e.   Within twenty feet (20') of the driveway entrance to any fire
station and on the side of a street opposite the entrance to any fire station
within seventy five feet (75') of such entrance (when properly signposted).
         f.   At any place where official signs prohibit standing.
      3.   Park a vehicle, whether occupied or not, except temporarily for the
purpose of and while actually engaged in loading or unloading property or
passengers:
         a.   Within fifty feet (50') of the nearest rail of a railroad
crossing;
         b.   At any place where official signs prohibit parking.
   B.   No person shall move a vehicle not lawfully under his control into any
such prohibited area or away from a curb such distance as is unlawful. (2016
Code)
7-5-3: PARKING PROHIBITED ON CERTAIN STREETS:
It shall be unlawful for an operator of any vehicle, including a motor vehicle,
motorcycle, trailer, semitrailer, truck-tractor, farm tractor, road tractor, or
road or construction equipment, to park for a longer time than indicated on the
roadway of a street where signs have been posted limiting the time or
prohibiting parking.
   A.   No Parking At Any Time: It shall be unlawful for an operator of any
vehicle, including a motor vehicle, motorcycle, moped, trailer, semitrailer,
truck-tractor, farm tractor, road tractor, or road or construction equipment,
to park or stand at any time on the roadway of the following streets: (1985
Code § 6-5-3)
   Catherine Ann Drive.
East Avenue, from the south roadway line of U.S. 66 (Joliet Road) to the south
line of 67th Street.
River Road, from the south side of 67th Street to its eastern terminus. Said
road shall be designated a tow away zone and subject to immediate tow.
Santa Fe Drive, from the south line of 67th Street to its western terminus.
Such drive shall be designated a tow away zone and subject to immediate tow.
U.S. Route 45 (LaGrange Road).
67th Street, from the east roadway line of U.S. 45 (LaGrange Road) to the east
street line of East Avenue.
(1985 Code § 6-5-3; amd. Ord. 91-45, 11-11-1991; Ord. 06-22, 12-11-2006)
   B.   No Parking In Certain Areas Of Certain Streets: It shall be unlawful to
park any vehicle on LaGrange Road, East Avenue, Joliet Road and 67th Street in
the following places: (Ord. 06-18, 10-9-2006)
      1.   Upon any part of the paved roadway.
      2.   Upon any part of the parkway. (1985 Code § 6-5-3)
7-5-4: SNOW ROUTES:
   A.   Parking Prohibited After Snowfall: It shall be unlawful to stand, stop
or park or cause to be parked a motor vehicle in any area or zone designated a
"snow route" after two inches (2") of snowfall or more until said snow is
completely removed. A vehicle parked in violation of this subsection is hereby
declared a nuisance and may be summarily abated, without notice, by towing upon
order of the police or the department of public works.
   B.   Applicability Of Provisions:
      1.   All streets or parts of streets marked "No Parking At Any Time" or
words of similar import are hereby designated as streets or parts of streets
subject to the provisions of subsection A of this section.
      2.   Any vehicle that is parked in violation of any parking ordinance or
law and is interfering with or about to interfere with snow removal operations
is made subject to the provisions of subsection A of this section.
   C.   Signs Posted: Street areas or zones designated as "snow routes" shall
be posted with signs stating that it is a "Snow Route - No Parking After Two
Inches (2") Of Snowfall Or More Until Removal Is Complete - And Vehicle Will Be
Towed".
   D.   Snow Routes Designated: The following streets are hereby designated as
snow routes throughout their entire length in the village:
East Avenue.
Joliet Road.
LaGrange Road.
67th Street.
   E.   Parking after two inches (2") of snow:
      1.   The following procedures shall be followed from November 1 through
April when snowfall of two inches (2") or more shall occur:
         a.   On odd numbered days there shall be parking only sides of streets
with odd numbers. For example, if more than two inches (2") of snowfall occurs
on January 1, all vehicles must be parked on sides of streets with odd numbers
or in the owner's driveway.
         b.   On even numbered days there shall be parking only on sides of
streets with even numbers. For example, if more than two inches (2") of
snowfall occurs on January 2, all vehicles must be parked on sides of streets
with even numbers or in the owner's driveway.
      2.   Residents parking on Cobb Street and Lyons Street: On even numbered
days there shall be parking only on the south side of the street. On odd
numbered days there shall be parking only on the north side of the street.
(1985 Code § 6-5-4; amd. Ord. 22-01, 2-14-2022)
7-5-5: STOPPING AND PARKING PROHIBITIONS AND RESTRICTIONS:
   A.   All Night Parking:
      1.   It shall be unlawful to park any of the following vehicles on any
street, alley, parkway or public driveway between the hours of seven o'clock
(7:00) P.M. and seven o'clock (7:00) A.M. of the following day:
         a.   Any second division vehicle as defined in state law with a gross
weight of eight thousand one (8,001) pounds or more;
         b.   Any bus;
         c.   Any tow truck;
         d.   Any trailer, including houseboats and camping trailers which are
not self-propelled;
         e.   Any passenger vehicle with a seating capacity of more than ten
(10) persons;
         f.   More than one commercial vehicle with a state class A or B plate,
per residence.
      2.   Such vehicles may park during said period for such time that is
necessary for the reasonable expeditious loading and unloading of the same when
making pick ups and deliveries.
   B.   Vehicle Loading And Unloading: It shall be unlawful to park any
vehicle, except a private passenger vehicle with a seating capacity of not more
than ten (10) persons, on any street for a longer period than is necessary for
the reasonable expeditious loading and unloading of such vehicle making pick
ups and deliveries.
   C.   Vehicle For Sale: It shall be unlawful to park any vehicle upon any
street for the purpose of displaying it for sale, or to park any vehicle upon
which merchandise is being offered to the public for sale.
   D.   Motor Running: No motor vehicle shall be left unattended while the
motor of said vehicle is running, or while standing upon a perceptible grade
without effectively setting the brake and turning the wheels of such vehicle
toward the curb or the side of the street or highway.
   E.   Street Cleaning: It shall be unlawful to park any vehicle upon any side
of the roadway of a street during the days and hours said roadway is being
swept or cleaned by the village. Official signs shall be posted by the public
works director at least four (4) hours before work is to begin and during the
hours and days said parking is prohibited. Such signs may be temporary in
nature but shall sufficiently inform the public of the prohibited time of
parking. The public works director is hereby authorized to remove, at the
expense of the owner, any vehicle parked in violation of this subsection.
   F.   Commercial District: It shall be lawful to park upon the roadway and
the parkway of any side street in a commercial district as defined in the
zoning title, provided the following requirements are met:
      1.   All areas to be blacktopped and kept in good repair.
      2.   Sidewalks shall be installed and kept clear for pedestrian traffic.
Allowance shall be made for location of sidewalks, with the approval of the
building and public works departments, to ensure adequate space for vehicles
without blocking sidewalks.
      3.   Wheel bumpers shall be required when necessary in the judgment of
the building department or the public works department.
      4.   Parking spaces shall be striped to ensure pedestrian right of way.
      5.   Parking spaces provided by this subsection shall not be counted or
included in the off street parking requirements provided in the zoning title.
(1985 Code § 6-5-5)
   G.   Resident Parking Only: As of the effective date hereof, there shall be
resident parking only on the west side of Lenzi Avenue at 6032 Lenzi. The
village clerk shall issue a sticker for each resident vehicle at those
addresses at no charge to the resident. (Ord. 91-45, 11-11-1991; amd. 2016
Code)
7-5-6: STOPPING OR PARKING CLOSE TO CURB:
   A.   Every vehicle stopped or parked on streets of the village forming a
part of the state or county highway or village street system, where there is an
adjacent curb, shall be so stopped or parked with the right hand wheels of such
vehicle parallel with and within twelve inches (12") of the right hand curb.
   B.   Except where angle parking is permitted by ordinance on streets other
than streets forming a part of the state or county highway or village street
system, every vehicle stopped or parked upon a roadway where there is an
adjacent curb shall be so stopped or parked with the right hand wheels of such
vehicle parallel with and within twelve inches (12") of the right hand curb.
(1985 Code § 6-5-6)
7-5-7: LIGHTS ON PARKED VEHICLES:
   A.   During the period from sunset to sunrise, every motorcycle or motor
vehicle occupied by a person which is standing on any street, highway, public
way, public park or public property shall display a parking light on the front
and at the rear of the same. Any lighted driving lamps within a parked vehicle
shall be depressed or dimmed.
   B.   Whenever an unoccupied vehicle is parked or stopped on a street during
the times between sunset or sunrise, or at any other time when there is not
sufficient light to render clearly discernible any vehicle on the street from a
distance of two hundred feet (200'), there shall be displayed upon said vehicle
one or more lights on the front of said vehicle and one or more red lights on
the rear of said vehicle, which shall be visible under normal atmospheric
conditions from a distance of two hundred feet (200'). (1985 Code § 6-5-7)
7-5-8: REMOVAL OF IMPROPERLY PARKED VEHICLES:
   A.   Any vehicle parked in violation of traffic regulations or parked so as
to obstruct the free movement of traffic or to cause a traffic hazard may be
immediately removed upon order of the police department to the village hall
parking lot, or to a public lot, garage or private lot so designated by the
village to serve as a storage for such removed vehicles. Any such vehicle
removed by the police department shall be kept under the control of the police
department until the owner or authorized agent pays a reasonable cost of
removal and storage in addition to the penalty provided for such improper
parking. Any such vehicle shall be deemed to be improperly parked in a
prohibited area or time after a period of three (3) minutes. If said vehicle is
redeemed, the cost of redemption shall include the actual cost and expense of
said removal in addition to a reasonable storage charge, and said costs and
expenses shall be a lien in favor of the village. Any lot zoned R or R-2 shall
not be permitted to store vehicles pursuant to this section.
   B.   Whenever any police officer finds a vehicle standing upon a street in
violation of any of the provisions of this chapter, such officer is authorized
to move such vehicle, or require the driver or other person in charge of the
vehicle to move the same, to a position off the paved or improved or main
traveled part of such street.
   C.   No person other than a police officer shall move a vehicle into any
prohibited area or away from a curb such distance as is unlawful or start or
cause to be started the motor of any motor vehicle, or shift, change or move
the levers, brake, starting device, gears or other mechanism of a standing
motor vehicle to a position other than that in which it was left by the owner
or driver thereof, or attempt so to do. (1985 Code § 6-5-8)
7-5-9: LIABILITY OF REGISTERED OWNER:
   A.   Whenever any vehicle shall have been parked in violation of any
provisions of this chapter prohibiting or restricting parking, the person in
whose name such vehicle is registered shall be prima facie responsible for such
violation and subject to penalty therefor.
   B.   Whenever any vehicle is parked in violation of the provisions of this
chapter prohibiting or restricting parking, and there is no person in
attendance upon such parked vehicle to be arrested or served immediately with a
notice to appear in court to answer the charge of such violation, any police
officer observing such violation may attach to the vehicle used in such
violation, a citation or ticket, so that the person in whose name such vehicle
is registered may answer the citation or appear in court on a day certain to be
named on such ticket, and answer to the charges of such violation. It shall be
unlawful for any person, other than the driver of the vehicle to which said
ticket or notification is attached, to remove same from said vehicle.
   C.   Every person in whose name a vehicle is registered pursuant to law and
who leases such vehicle to others, after receiving written notice of a
violation of this chapter or the statutes involving such vehicle, shall, upon
request, provide such police officers as have authority of the offense, and the
court having jurisdiction thereof, with a written statement of the name and
address of the lessee at the time of such offense and the identifying number
upon the registration plates of such vehicle. (1985 Code § 6-5-9)
CHAPTER 6
YIELD RIGHT OF WAY AND STOP INTERSECTIONS
SECTION:
7-6-1: Yield Right Of Way Intersections
7-6-2: Stop Intersections
7-6-3: Obedience To Stop And Yield Signs
7-6-1: YIELD RIGHT OF WAY INTERSECTIONS:
   A.   Signs Posted: Pursuant to state law, the public works director is
hereby ordered to erect yield signs upon direction of the village board of
trustees. Every sign shall be erected according to standards set forth in the
Illinois sign manual adopted by the state department of transportation. (1985
Code § 6-6-1; amd. 2016 Code)
   B.   Duty Of Driver When Approaching A Yield Sign: The driver of a vehicle
approaching a yield sign shall:
      1.   If required for safety to stop, stop before entering the crosswalk
on the near side of the intersection or, in the event there is no crosswalk, at
a clearly marked stop line, but if none, then at the point nearest the
intersecting roadway where the driver has a view of approaching traffic on the
intersecting roadway. At marked crosswalks not at an intersection, the driver
shall stop at the near side of the crosswalk and yield the right of way to all
pedestrians thereon before proceeding across it.
      2.   In obedience to such sign, slow down to a speed reasonable for the
existing conditions and shall yield the right of way to any vehicle in the
intersection or approaching on another highway so closely as to constitute an
immediate hazard during the time such driver is moving across or within the
intersection. (1985 Code § 6-6-1)
7-6-2: STOP INTERSECTIONS:
   A.   Duty Of Driver When Approaching A Stop Sign: Except when directed to
proceed by a police officer or traffic control signal, every driver of a
vehicle approaching a stop intersection indicated by a stop sign shall:
      1.   Stop before entering the crosswalk on the near side of the
intersection or, in the event there is no crosswalk, shall stop at a clearly
marked stop line, but if none, then at the point nearest the intersecting
roadway where the driver has a view of approaching traffic on the intersecting
roadway before entering the intersection.
      2.   Stop as required by subsection A1 of this section and, after having
stopped, shall yield the right of way to any vehicle which has entered the
intersection from another highway or street or which is approaching so closely
on said highway or street as to constitute an immediate hazard during the time
when such driver is moving across or within the intersection. (1985 Code § 6-6-
2)

7-6-3: OBEDIENCE TO STOP AND YIELD SIGNS:
All stop signs or yield signs erected at the effective date hereof are hereby
determined to be stop or yield signs to which vehicles shall stop or yield and
obey. (1985 Code § 6-6-3)
CHAPTER 7
TRAFFIC VIOLATIONS AND PENALTIES
SECTION:
7-7-1: Impoundment Of Vehicles
7-7-2: Liability Of Vehicle Owner And Driver
7-7-3: Violations By Minors
7-7-4: Joint Enforcement Of Traffic Control On Joliet Road
7-7-5: Citations
7-7-6: Penalty
7-7-1: IMPOUNDMENT OF VEHICLES:
Every vehicle which shall have been used in violation of any of the provisions
of this title is hereby declared to be a nuisance and may be summarily abated
by any police officer by removing and conveying, or causing the removal and
conveyance of, such vehicle to the vehicle pound or pounds designated by the
village president. For this purpose, any area adjacent to a police station may
be declared to be a vehicle pound. Before the owner or person entitled to
possession of any legally impounded vehicle shall be permitted to remove the
same, he shall furnish evidence of ownership or right to possession and shall
pay for the cost of towing or removal to the vehicle pound and the cost of
storage for each day or fraction thereof in said pound. (1985 Code § 6-7-1)
7-7-2: LIABILITY OF VEHICLE OWNER AND DRIVER:
Whenever a driver of a motor vehicle is not the owner of such vehicle, but is
operating, driving or moving the same with the express or implied permission of
the owner, the owner and driver are jointly and severally liable for the
penalties provided in this chapter. Recovery, if not had in the court in which
the citation is issued for the violation, may be had in any civil action. (1985
Code § 6-7-2)
7-7-3: VIOLATIONS BY MINORS:
   A.   Detaining Child: It shall be the duty of all police officers, on
discovering that any person who has violated any of the provisions of this
title is a person under the age of eighteen (18) years, to inquire as to the
name, age and last residence of such person and to promptly notify the parent,
guardian or custodian of said child that the child has been detained for
violation of the provisions of this title and to report to the police station
for the return of said child to his custody. Whenever it is impractical to do
so, the said child may be returned forthwith to his home but in no case shall
the motor vehicle being used by said child be returned to him. It is the duty
of the parent, guardian or custodian of said child to recover said motor
vehicle.
   B.   Parental Responsibility: It shall be unlawful for any parent, guardian,
custodian or other person to knowingly permit a child to violate any of the
provisions of this title. It shall be presumed that said parent, guardian,
custodian or any person knowingly permits the same when said child has
committed his second offense for violating the provisions of this title or any
other traffic ordinance or law, whether or not found guilty. (1985 Code § 6-7-
3)
7-7-4: JOINT ENFORCEMENT OF TRAFFIC CONTROL ON JOLIET ROAD:
The village of Hodgkins, Cook County, Illinois, and the city of Countryside,
Cook County, Illinois, shall have joint jurisdiction for the enforcement of all
laws of the state of Illinois, and all of their respective ordinances,
pertaining to the regulation and control of motor vehicles and motor vehicle
traffic on both sides of Joliet Road, between the west line of LaGrange Road
and the east line of East Avenue. (1985 Code § 6-7-4)
7-7-5: CITATIONS:
A police or peace officer may, in lieu of the issuance of a traffic ticket
summons or a complaint in the circuit court, issue alleged violators a P ticket
as described in section
7-1-2 of this title for those violations enumerated in section
7-1-2 of this title. (1985 Code § 6-7-5)
7-7-6: PENALTY:
Any person violating any of the provisions of this title, when no other penalty
is provided, shall be fined not less than twenty five dollars ($25.00) nor more
than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each offense, and a separate
offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation
occurs or continues. (1985 Code § 6-7-6; amd. 2016 Code)
TITLE 8
PUBLIC WAYS AND PROPERTY
CHAPTER 1
PUBLIC WORKS DEPARTMENT
SECTION:
8-1-1: Superintendent Of Public Works And Water
8-1-2: Combined Water And Sewer Department
8-1-1: SUPERINTENDENT OF PUBLIC WORKS AND WATER:
   A.   Appointment; Functions: The superintendent of public works and water
shall be appointed by the village president, with the advice and consent of the
board of trustees. The superintendent may use the title of director and may be
known as the director or superintendent of public works and water. The
superintendent or director shall have jurisdiction over and shall be
responsible for the management, control and maintenance of the streets, parks
where owned by the village, sidewalks, garbage disposal, water and sewer,
public grounds, public buildings and all other public works and services which
may be operated by the village.
   B.   Powers And Duties:
      1.   General Supervision: The superintendent shall have supervision over
all buildings and equipment used in the furnishing of water in the village, and
shall provide that the object and purposes of the water department are carried
out and that the combined waterworks and sewerage system is conducted on an
economical, businesslike basis, and for this purpose, it shall be the duty of
the superintendent and all of the officers, employees and servants of said
department to enforce all the provisions of this title and to observe and obey
and carry out the orders and directions of the president and village board.
Where the streets are required to be opened for repairs or extensions, the
superintendent shall cooperate with the street department for the protection of
the public against accidents during such repairs and extensions. He shall
prepare and keep in his office a complete atlas of the waterworks and sewerage
system, with all valves, hydrants, water service connections, sewer mains,
house connections and other appurtenances distinctly recorded therein.
      2.   Reports: The superintendent shall, upon the first of each and every
month, or more often if required, submit a report in writing to the village
president and board of trustees of gallons of water purchased, gallons of water
sold, number of metered users, all monies collected by him, the account whereon
collected, and of any and all other matters connected with his office.
      3.   Accounting: The superintendent shall keep, or cause to be kept, full
and complete books of accounts showing in detail all monies received by him,
with dates and sources, and all matters pertaining to his office in a clear and
methodical manner. He shall also keep such books as the president and board of
trustees may from time to time direct. All such books, accounts and papers
pertaining to said office shall at all times be open to the inspection of the
president and board of trustees or any member or committee thereof. (1985 Code
§ 7-1-1)
      4.   Deposit Monies: The superintendent shall, within forty eight (48)
hours of receipt by him, deposit to the credit of the village water and sewer
fund in the depository designated by the president and board of trustees, all
monies collected by him from any source whatever, taking such depository's
receipt in triplicate therefor, one of which receipts he shall immediately file
with the village clerk and another with the village comptroller. He is
expressly prohibited from keeping the monies of the village in his hands, or in
the hands of any person or corporation to his use, beyond the time which is
herein prescribed. Any violation of this subsection shall subject the
superintendent to immediate removal from office. Custody and control of all
funds collected shall be with the village comptroller. (1985 Code § 7-1-1; amd.
2016 Code)
      5.   Read Meters; Collect Payments; Issue Permits: The superintendent, or
such officer or employee of the department as he shall direct, shall read water
meters, collect the water rates, issue water permits and perform such other
duties as are or may hereafter be imposed upon him by law or this code.
   C.   Bond: Before entering upon the duties of his office, the superintendent
of the department shall execute a bond to the village in the penal sum of five
thousand dollars ($5,000.00) with corporate sureties to be approved by the
board of trustees, conditioned as prescribed by law. The cost of such corporate
surety bond shall be paid by the village. (1985 Code § 7-1-1)
8-1-2: COMBINED WATER AND SEWER DEPARTMENT:
   A.   Departments Combined: The waterworks system and the sewerage system in
the village shall be maintained and operated together as a combined waterworks
and sewerage system, and hereinafter in this section, where the term department
or water department is used, it shall be considered to mean the combined water
and sewer department, unless the context clearly indicates otherwise. The
combined water and sewer department shall be under the direction of the
superintendent of public works and water.
   B.   Jurisdiction: The water department, under the direction of the
superintendent and such other officers and employees as may be from time to
time lawfully appointed, shall have the supervision, management and control,
subject to the president and board of trustees, of the maintenance, enlargement
and operation of the combined waterworks and sewerage system owned and
controlled by the village, the procuring and selling of water, and all matters
and things connected with the operation, maintenance and extension of said
combined waterworks and sewerage system, and preserving the property belonging
thereto.
   C.   Certified Licensed Operator: The president is authorized to employ a
certified licensed operator to conduct and supervise the operation of the water
department. He may seek help from and employ persons employed by other
municipalities on a part time or full time basis.
   D.   Compensation: The superintendent and other officers and employees of
the department shall receive as compensation for their services amounts to be
fixed by the board of trustees from time to time or as provided by the annual
appropriation ordinance. (1985 Code § 7-1-2)
CHAPTER 2
STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND PUBLIC WAYS
SECTION:
8-2-1: Control And Supervision
8-2-2: Construction Requirements
8-2-3: Repairs And Defects
8-2-4: Use Of Public Ways
8-2-5: Dedications
8-2-6: Building Numbering
8-2-7: Excavations
8-2-8: Barricades And Warning Lights
8-2-9: Obstructions
8-2-10: Sidewalks, Driveways And Parkways
8-2-11: Prohibited Acts And Conditions
8-2-12: Deposits On Streets And Sidewalks
8-2-13: State Regulations Adopted; Amendments
8-2-1: CONTROL AND SUPERVISION:
   A.   Control: All streets, public alleys and thoroughfares in the village
shall be the property of the village, under the control and management of the
president and board of trustees; and no additional streets or alleys shall be
created, and no existing streets or alleys shall be closed without the
permission of the village board.
   B.   Supervision: All public streets, alleys, sidewalks and other public
ways in the village shall be under the supervision of the superintendent of
public works and water 1 . He shall be charged with the enforcement of all
ordinance provisions relating to such public places (except traffic ordinances)
and is hereby authorized to enforce such ordinances. (1985 Code § 7-2-1)
 
Notes
1 1. See also section
  8-1-1 of this title.
8-2-2: CONSTRUCTION REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Permit Required; Application: It shall be unlawful to construct or lay
any pavement or any public street, sidewalk, alley or other public way, or to
repair the same, without first having secured a permit therefor. Applications
for such permit shall be made to the village clerk and shall state the location
of the intended pavement or repair, the extent thereof, and the person who is
to do the actual construction work. No such permit shall be issued except on
order of the village board.
   B.   Bond: Each applicant shall file a bond in the amount provided by
subsection
8-2-9A of this chapter with surety to be approved by the village board,
conditioned to indemnify the village for any loss or damage resulting from the
work undertaken or the manner of doing the same.
   C.   Specifications:
      1.   General: All street and sidewalk pavements shall be made in
conformity with specifications laid down or approved from time to time by the
village board.
      2.   Width:
         a.   All streets in the village shall be sixty six feet (66') wide
with the following exceptions:
            (1)   Section line streets shall be one hundred feet (100') wide.
            (2)   Half section line streets shall be eighty feet (80') wide.
            (3)   Streets of different width may be permitted, provided such
width is approved by the zoning board.
         b.   The curb line for industrial streets sixty six feet (66') wide
shall be a distance of nineteen feet (19') from the middle of the street. The
curb line for all other streets shall be set by the village board.
      3.   Grade: Grade levels prevailing at the effective date hereof shall be
the official grades for all thoroughfares flanked by one or more houses;
provided, however, that in any block where no houses are located, no grade
level will be deemed to exist. Prior to erection of any edifice in any block
where no grade level is established, the owner or contractor erecting such
edifice shall make application to the village board for the establishment of a
grade level. The term "grade level", with regard to existing levels, shall be
understood to mean the crown of any thoroughfare currently maintained by the
village, county or state. (1985 Code § 7-2-2)
      4.   Ramped Sidewalks: Any sidewalk constructed or repaired after the
effective date hereof shall be ramped anywhere that the sidewalk under
construction or repair meets a street, alley, parking lot or other interruption
to ensure accessibility to persons with disabilities in accordance with
specifications set forth in applicable law. (Ord. 92-20, 6-8-1992; amd. 2016
Code)
   D.   Streets Cleaned: The permittee shall be responsible for maintaining the
streets in a reasonably clean condition. However, as construction work does
produce mud and dirt on the streets and in storm sewer catch basins, there
shall be a fee paid for street cleaning before a permit is issued. (1985 Code §
7-2-2)
8-2-3: REPAIRS AND DEFECTS:
All public street, alley and sidewalk pavements shall be kept in good repair.
Such repair work, whether done by the village or by the abutting owner, shall
be under the supervision of the superintendent. It shall be the duty of every
village officer or employee becoming cognizant of any defect in any street,
alley or sidewalk, or any obstruction thereof, to report the same to the
superintendent as soon as possible. (1985 Code § 7-2-3)
8-2-4: USE OF PUBLIC WAYS:
   A.   Private Use: It shall be unlawful for any person to use any street,
sidewalk or other public place as space for the display or sale of goods or
merchandise, or to write or mark any signs or advertisements on any such
pavement.
   B.   Poles And Wires: It shall be unlawful to erect or maintain any poles or
wires on or over any public street, alley or other public way without having
first secured permission from the village board. (1985 Code § 7-2-4)
8-2-5: DEDICATIONS:
In accordance with the practice universally followed heretofore, when any plat
is submitted to the board for approval or when any portion of land is to be
dedicated to the village for a public thoroughfare, such dedication or plat
shall be accompanied by an instrument conveying full title to the village,
instead of easement rights, in the portion to become a public thoroughfare.
(1985 Code § 7-2-5)
8-2-6: BUILDING NUMBERING:
Each building in the village shall be designated by a number, which number
shall be visible in the front thereof and be of such size and clarity as to be
easily deciphered from the curb line of the street. A number shall be assigned
to each building by the building inspector and shall be determined in
accordance with the numbering system currently prevailing in the city of
Chicago, being merely an extension thereof. The owner of any building in the
village who does not ascertain and post his number in accordance with the
provisions of this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, punishable by
fine. Any dispute arising out of the number of any building shall be determined
by resolution of the village board. (1985 Code § 7-2-6; amd. 2016 Code)
8-2-7: EXCAVATIONS:
   A.   Permit Required; Application: It shall be unlawful to make any opening,
excavation or tunnel in any public street, alley, sidewalk or other public
place in the village without having first secured a permit therefor.
Applications for such permits shall be made to the village clerk and shall
specify the intended location and purpose of the excavation.
   B.   Deposit: In each case, the applicant shall agree to pay all of the
costs of restoring such street, alley, sidewalk or other public place and the
surface thereof to the condition that existed before the opening, excavation or
tunnel was made. No such permit shall be issued until the applicant has
deposited with the superintendent the sum of one hundred dollars ($100.00) for
each such opening, excavation or tunnel, which such deposit shall be deposited
by the applicant and used by the village for the purpose of paying the cost of
restoring such street, alley, sidewalk or other public place and the surface
thereof to the condition that existed before the opening, excavation or tunnel
was made; provided, that the applicant shall, in each case, do all necessary
backfilling or cause the same to be done. In restoring such street, alley,
sidewalk or other public place, the village may use its own employees and
equipment and make reasonable charges therefor, or it may engage the services
of other persons and equipment and charge the cost thereof to the applicant.
Any balance of said deposit remaining after the deduction of such charges or
costs shall be returned to the applicant, and any charges over the deposit
collected from said applicant. In case said applicant shall restore said street
to its original condition, said applicant shall be entitled to the return of
his deposit after one year from the date of application or restoration,
whichever is later; otherwise said deposit may be used as specified herein.
   C.   Bond: No such permit shall be issued unless the applicant has on file
with the village and in full force and effect, a bond in the amount of ten
thousand dollars ($10,000.00) with surety to be approved by the village,
conditioned to indemnify the village against any and all loss or liability
resulting from the making of such opening, excavation or tunnel.
   D.   Supervision: All such openings, excavations, tunnels, refills and
resurfacing shall be made subject to the supervision of the superintendent.
(1985 Code § 7-2-7)
8-2-8: BARRICADES AND WARNING LIGHTS:
   A.   Any person laying or repairing any pavement on a street, sidewalk or
other public place, or making an excavation in any such place, shall maintain
suitable barricades to prevent injury to any person or vehicle by reason of the
work. Such barricades shall be protected by lights at nighttime.
Any defects in any such pavement shall be barricaded to prevent any injury, and
any person properly maintaining any opening or excavation in any such place
shall guard such opening or excavation while the same remains open by proper
barricades and lights.
   B.   All pits, excavations, fences, barriers, builder's equipment, building
materials or rubbish in or upon a street, alley, sidewalk or any other public
space shall have placed upon or by them illuminated lamps with red globes,
flares or other approved lights, in such manner that there shall be one light
at each end, and at intermediate points, as may be necessary to afford proper
warning after darkness.
   C.   Excavations shall be fenced.
   D.   It shall be unlawful to disturb or interfere with any barricade or
lights lawfully placed to protect or mark any new pavement or excavation or
opening in any public street, alley or sidewalk. (1985 Code § 7-2-8)
8-2-9: OBSTRUCTIONS:
   A.   Bond: Before the superintendent shall issue a street obstruction
permit, the applicant for such permit shall file with the clerk, on a form to
be furnished by the village and approved by the village attorney, a bond in the
penal sum of not less than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) and conditioned to
indemnify, save and keep harmless the village from any and all loss, costs,
expense or liability of any kind whatsoever to which the village may suffer or
be put, or which may be recovered therefrom by reason of the issuance of such
permit, or by reason of any act or thing done or neglected to be done, under or
by virtue of the authority given in such permit. An annual bond may be given to
cover street obstruction permits.
   B.   Permit Fee And Deposit: The fee to be paid to the village for a street
occupation permit desired in connection with any work governed by this chapter
shall be one dollar ($1.00) for each month for each one foot (1') or fractional
part thereof of frontage so occupied. In addition to such permit fee, a deposit
shall be required to ensure the safety of the street and its complete
restoration, of not less than ten dollars ($10.00) per foot. Upon the removal
of such obstruction, so much (if any) of said deposit as shall be necessary to
restore said street shall be retained by the village, and the remainder of said
deposit shall then be returned to the depositor; provided, however, that
nothing herein contained shall preclude the village from maintaining an action
against the person to recover the damage done to any street or sidewalk. (1985
Code § 7-2-9; amd. 2016 Code)
8-2-10: SIDEWALKS, DRIVEWAYS AND PARKWAYS:
   A.   Installation And Maintenance Responsibilities Of Contiguous Owners:
      1.   Public sidewalks shall be installed on all public rights of way, as
per village requirements, by the owner of the contiguous premises. If the
existing sidewalk is in bad repair or cracked, the public sidewalk shall be
replaced by the owner of the contiguous premises who shall indemnify, hold
harmless and defend the village, its officers, agents, employees and
representatives against any and all liability for losses, expenses, damages,
injuries, demands, claims and fees (including attorney fees) in conjunction
with or arising out of any injury, death or damage to any person or property
sustained or alleged to have been sustained on or arising from the sidewalk or
parkway contiguous to his property.
      2.   It shall be the duty of each person residing on property abutting on
the village streets to maintain the area between his lot line and the curb line
free from weeds and other noxious herbage or matter.
      3.   Any person issued a license or permit by the village to do or
conduct a business therein shall keep and maintain the public sidewalk and
parkway in good repair and to keep the public sidewalk free from snow and ice.
   B.   Construction Requirements; Bond: The sidewalk installation bond shall
be deposited with the village in cash based on ten dollars ($10.00) per linear
foot. The sidewalk bond is in addition to any other bond required in this
chapter. A twenty five dollar ($25.00) inspection fee shall be paid for each
bond required on each and every site.
   C.   Construction Specifications:
      1.   Sidewalks: The following standard specifications for the
construction of public sidewalks shall be followed in all cases: portland
cement concrete sidewalks, section 6724 of "Standard Specifications For Road
And Bridge Construction", adopted July 1, 1976, Illinois department of
transportation. The village shall furnish said specifications at the time the
permit is given.
      2.   Driveways Over Public Property: Driveways shall be constructed of
concrete materials or a bituminous aggregate mixture. The concrete shall be at
least seven inches (7") in thickness and have the same base and mixtures and
shall be laid as provided for public sidewalks in subsection C1 of this
section. The bituminous aggregate mixture shall be at least two inches (2") in
thickness with a nine inch (9") stone base.
      3.   Sidewalks And Driveways: Public sidewalks and driveways shall have a
two inch (2") in diameter galvanized iron rigid pipe or conduit extended under
it one foot (1') outside the sidewalk line in the parkway running the full
width of said sidewalk or driveway, eighteen inches (18") below finished grade.
All public sidewalks and driveways shall be paved as herein provided, and no
public sidewalk or driveway shall be laid or constructed without first securing
a permit. (1985 Code § 7-2-10)
      4.   Ramped Sidewalks: Any sidewalk constructed or repaired after the
effective date hereof shall be ramped anywhere that the sidewalk under
construction or repair meets a street, alley, parking lot or other
interruption, to ensure accessibility to persons with disabilities in
accordance with specifications set forth in applicable law. (Ord. 92-20, 6-8-
1992; amd. 2016 Code)
   D.   Parkway Beautification:
      1.   Public parkways shall be planted in grass in all zoning districts,
except for:
         a.   Driveways crossing the parkway.
         b.   Parkways on Joliet Road, or parkways which are contiguous to
property owned or used by a political subdivision, municipal corporation,
public institution, or a not for profit institution may be paved for parking if
the public sidewalk is installed.
      2.   The village hereby grants revocable permission for each citizen to
beautify the operation of land owned by the village and located between his
premises and the adjoining curb line; provided, however, that no encumbrance
other than bushes, grass, flowers, trees and decorative rocks shall be
established thereon. Fences, fenceposts, wires and any other type of
encumbrance is strictly prohibited. Such permission shall include all other
rights of possession exercisable against all but the duly appointed or elected
representatives of the village acting in official capacity, and action for
trespass may be brought by the adjoining owner with regard to such portion of
land, exclusive of the area occupied by the public sidewalk. (1985 Code § 7-2-
10)
8-2-11: PROHIBITED ACTS AND CONDITIONS:
   A.   Injury To Pavements:
      1.   It shall be unlawful to walk upon or drive any vehicle or animal
upon, or injure any newly laid street or sidewalk pavement while the same is
guarded by a warning sign or barricade, or to knowingly injure any soft, newly
laid pavement.
      2.   No tractor, traction engine, motor truck or other similar vehicle
shall be operated across, over or along any street in the village if any such
vehicle has on the periphery of any of the road wheels any block, stud, flange,
cleat, ridge, or lug or any projection of metal or wood which projects
radically beyond the tread or traffic surface of the tire; except, that this
prohibition shall not apply to tractors or traction engines equipped with what
is known as crawler type tractors, when the same does not contain any
projections of any kind likely to injure the surface of the road, nor to
tractors, traction engines and similar vehicles which have upon their road
wheels V-shaped, diagonal or other cleats arranged in such a manner as to be
continuously in contact with the road surface. In no event shall the surface of
any street be used as an area or space for turning any tractor or other farm
machinery in carrying on or performing any farming operations upon the adjacent
land. Provided, that nothing in this subsection shall prohibit the operation of
tractors, traction engines or motor trucks across any street in order to reach
adjacent lands if the street is protected by solid planks or other suitable
devices to prevent such vehicle from injuring the surface thereof.
   B.   Obstructions:
      1.   It shall be unlawful for any person to cause, create or maintain any
obstruction of any street, alley, sidewalk or other public way, except as may
be specifically authorized by ordinance or by the superintendent.
      2.   It shall be unlawful to obstruct any drain in any public street or
alley. (1985 Code § 7-2-11)
8-2-12: DEPOSITS ON STREETS AND SIDEWALKS:
   A.   Streets: It shall be unlawful to deposit on any street any material
which may be harmful to the pavement thereof, or any waste material, or any
glass or any articles which may do injury to any person, animal or property.
Coal or other materials may be deposited in streets preparatory to delivery or
use, provided such deposit does not reduce the usable width of the roadway at
the point to less than eighteen feet (18'); provided, that such material,
equipment or coal, other than material or equipment to be used in actual
building construction, shall not be permitted to remain on such street for more
than three (3) hours. Any such material, equipment or coal shall be guarded by
lights if the same remains upon any street after dark. (1985 Code § 7-2-12;
amd. 2016 Code)
   B.   Sidewalks: It shall be unlawful to deposit on any public sidewalk any
material which may be harmful to the pavement thereof, or any waste material,
or any glass or other articles which might cause injury to persons, animals or
property. Merchandise or other articles may be deposited on sidewalks
preparatory to delivery; provided, that the usable width of the walk is not
thereby reduced to less than four feet (4'); and provided further, that no such
article shall remain on such walk for more than one-half (1/2) hour. (1985 Code
§ 7-2-12)
8-2-13: STATE REGULATIONS ADOPTED; AMENDMENTS:
   A.   Adoption Of State Regulations: The "State Of Illinois Department Of
Transportation District One Permit Special Provisions", latest edition, revised
November 1990, a copy of which is attached to the ordinance codified herein and
made a part hereof, for any and all work performed by contractors on its
streets and rights of way, is hereby adopted except as revised in subsection B
of this section.
   B.   Amendments: The following amendments and revisions shall be made to the
document adopted in subsection A of this section:
Wherever the words "state" and "department" appear, they shall mean "village of
Hodgkins"; and wherever any reference to the words "district one permit office"
appear, they shall mean the "village of Hodgkins superintendent of public works
and water".
Section H: The following language shall be added:
At the contractor's option, full depth class D bituminous patches in accordance
with the attached IDOT standard 2427-1, may be used in lieu of full depth
concrete patches in areas where the existing pavement is bituminous or
aggregate. Patches shall be minimum 12" thick with 10" bituminous base course
in accordance with section 355 of the standard specification and 2" bituminous
concrete surface course class I in accordance with article 406 of the standard
specifications.
Section K: The following language shall be deleted:
All references to seeding. Only Illinois department of transportation approved
sod will be allowed for restoration of parkway landscaping. Fertilizer shall be
applied as per section K, and topsoil shall be pulverized virgin topsoil, 4"
minimum compacted thickness.
      (Ord. 94-7, 5-9-1994)
CHAPTER 3
WATERWORKS AND SEWERAGE SYSTEM
ARTICLE A. COMBINED SYSTEM
SECTION:
8-3A-1: Use Of Public System
8-3A-2: Rules And Regulations
8-3A-3: Special Connections
8-3A-4: Revenues
8-3A-5: Authority To Change Regulations
8-3A-6: Nonliability Of Village
8-3A-7: Enforcement
8-3A-8: Penalty
8-3A-1: USE OF PUBLIC SYSTEM:
   A.   Required: No building requiring toilet facilities or the use of water
for human consumption shall be constructed or used without being serviced by
the sanitary sewer and waterworks system provided by the village.
   B.   Privies: Outside privies are hereby prohibited.
   C.   Chemical Toilets: Temporary chemical toilet facilities may be used
where the contents are removed each day. Such chemical toilets shall be subject
to approval of the health officer.
   D.   Purchase Of Water; Securing Sewage Facilities: No person having his
residence or place of business within the territorial limits of the village, or
in an unincorporated area within one thousand feet (1,000') of the village,
shall be permitted to buy water or secure sewage facilities from any other
municipal corporation or other public utility for such residence or place of
business located in the village or in an unincorporated area within one
thousand feet (1,000') of the village whenever the water or sewer, or both, of
the waterworks and sewerage system of the village is adjacent or available to
his property. (1985 Code § 7-3A-1)
8-3A-2: RULES AND REGULATIONS:
Water consumers, licensed plumbers and others shall be governed by the
following rules and regulations:
   A.   Supervision: All work done in the streets and alleys or public places
of the village in connection with the sewer and water system shall be done in a
thorough and workmanlike manner and shall be under the supervision and
direction of the superintendent and subject to his approval.
   B.   Permits Required:
      1.   No connection shall be made with the sewer and water system without
proper permit from the combined water and sewer department.
      2.   No alteration, change of location or addition of any kind shall be
made to any water meter, water cock or service pipe connected in any way with
the supply to any building or premises without first obtaining a written permit
from the village superintendent.
   C.   Construction Specifications:
      1.   No water service pipe shall be laid nearer than eighteen inches
(18") from a parallel trench, and all service pipe shall be laid so as to
prevent freezing, breaking or rupture by settling.
      2.   A gooseneck shall be provided for each service pipe and must be
supported by means of brick built up from the bottom of the trench. (1985 Code
§ 7-3A-2)
      3.   The installation of all service pipe must be done in a workmanlike
manner under the supervision of the superintendent, and shall withstand a test
of one hundred fifty (150) pounds' pressure for a period of two (2) hours
without leaking.
      4.   There shall be a shutoff provided for every connection or top, which
shutoff must be in what is commonly called a buffalo box. Said buffalo box
shall be located as near the outer sidewalk edge as conditions will permit.
Each and every meter shall be set in a meter vault of not less than eighteen
inches (18") in internal diameter with a steel or cast iron lid or cover,
except where there are heated basements, in which event, the meter may be
installed in such basement. The pipe to be used in construction of the service
pipe from the shutoff box to the meter shall be of copper of the same
specifications as hereinbefore prescribed for the service pipe between the
water main and the shutoff box. (1985 Code § 7-3A-2; amd. 2016 Code)
      5.   All earth removed in excavating for the sewer and water service
pipes shall be returned to the trenches from which it was taken and shall be
replaced in layers not exceeding six inches (6") in depth. Each layer shall be
thoroughly compacted by ramming, and the earth shall be moistened sufficiently
to permit the return of all the earth to the trenches by ramming as above
specified. When required by the superintendent, sand shall be used as a
backfill, and excess earth shall be removed as directed by the superintendent.
When completed, the surface of the backfilling in the trenches shall not be
higher than the general surface of the ground on either side of same, and the
roadways of all streets shall be retained and shall be maintained for a period
of one year in as good condition for travel as they were before the
commencement of said work. (1985 Code § 7-3A-2)
      6.   All plumbing work shall be done by a licensed plumber. A complete
statement in writing shall be made to the comptroller by the person doing the
work of all connections made with the sewer and water system. This information
shall be used for purposes of billing for service charges. (1985 Code § 7-3A-2;
amd. 2016 Code)
   D.   Additional Apparatus:
      1.   Boilers: All boilers connected with the sewer and water system shall
be provided with a tank of sufficient capacity to hold at least six (6) hours'
supply, and in case this supply is shut off for the purpose of repair or any
other purpose, the village will not be responsible for any damage that may
result. Consumers and other persons are prohibited from connecting pipes
directly with the village pressure to supply steam boilers.
      2.   Booster Pumps: No booster pump or other apparatus intended to
increase water pressure shall be installed unless a tank or reservoir is
provided between the meter and such pump or apparatus. Said tank or reservoir
shall be covered, and shall be provided with a vent or overflow to the
atmosphere, and shall be so designed as to prevent a direct hydraulic
connection between the meter and the pump or pressure increasing apparatus.
   E.   Hydrants: All hydrants or plugs placed in the village for fire purposes
are hereby declared to be the public hydrants, and no person, except such as
has been authorized by the board of trustees, shall open or draw water
therefrom, or in any manner interfere with same except in case of fire. (1985
Code § 7-3A-2)
   F.   Inspections: The superintendent and the village comptroller and other
authorized persons shall have free access to any premises in which water is
introduced for the purpose of examining the fixtures and pipes at any time
between the hours of seven o'clock (7:00) A.M. and six o'clock (6:00) P.M. of
any day. (1985 Code § 7-3A-2; amd. 2016 Code)
8-3A-3: SPECIAL CONNECTIONS:
Any person, being a regular consumer, may be permitted by the board of trustees
to make special connections with the street mains, together with hydrants and
house cocks, to be used in case of fire. For such permit, and for all water
used for fire purposes, there will be no charge, but all such work in
connection with the sewer and water system must be done by the village or under
the direction of the superintendent of public works and water. (1985 Code § 7-
3A-3)
8-3A-4: REVENUES:
   A.   Rates And Charges: A charge shall be made to the residents of the
village, which shall be reasonable, for the use and service of the waterworks
and sewerage system; and such charges or rates for that purpose shall be
established; and such rates shall be sufficient to pay the costs, maintenance,
operation, depreciation and payment of the principal and interest on any
revenue bonds that may be issued by the village for the construction,
installation, repairing and improving of said combined system.
   B.   Monies Kept Separate; Deposits: All revenues and monies derived from
the operation of the combined waterworks and sewerage system shall be held by
the superintendent separate and apart from his private funds and separate and
apart from all other funds of the village; and all of said sums, without any
deductions whatsoever, shall be delivered to the village depository not more
than seven (7) days after the receipt of same, or at such more frequent
intervals as may from time to time be directed by the village president and
board of trustees. (1985 Code § 7-3A-4)
   C.   Waterworks And Sewerage Fund: The village comptroller shall receive all
such revenues from the combined waterworks and sewerage system and all other
funds and monies incident to the operation of said system as the same may be
delivered to him and deposit the same in a separate fund designated as the
"waterworks and sewerage fund of the village of Hodgkins". The comptroller
shall administer said fund in every respect in the manner provided by the
statutes of the state of Illinois.
   D.   Accounting: The village comptroller shall establish a proper system of
accounts in which complete and correct entries shall be made of all
transactions relative to the waterworks and sewerage system, and at regular
annual intervals, he shall cause to be made, under the direction of the village
president and board of trustees, an audit by an independent auditing concern of
the books to show the receipts and disbursements of the combined sewer and
water system. (1985 Code § 7-3A-4; amd. 2016 Code)
8-3A-5: AUTHORITY TO CHANGE REGULATIONS:
Nothing contained in this article shall prevent the village from changing or
altering the provisions hereof, and the village shall have and retain authority
from time to time to change, increase, decrease or improve the system and
plant, or any part or portion thereof, or to establish new or different rates,
regulations or provisions concerning the use of the water and sewer system or
plant, or to alter, amend, change or repeal the provisions of this article.
(1985 Code § 7-3A-5)
8-3A-6: NONLIABILITY OF VILLAGE:
   A.   All connections and water applied for hereunder, and all the water used
hereunder, shall be upon the express condition that the village shall not be
liable, nor shall any claim be made against it, for damage or injury caused by
reason of the breakage of any main, branches, service pipes, apparatus or
appurtenances connected with the system or plant, or any part or portion of the
plant, or for any interruption of the supply by reason of the breakage of
machinery or by reason of stoppage, alteration, extension and renewals.
   B.   All repairs to service pipes and connections therefrom shall be at the
expense of the owner or tenant of the premises supplied, except repairs on the
section of the pipe included between the corporation cock at the main and the
curb cock in the parkway. (1985 Code § 7-3A-6)
8-3A-7: ENFORCEMENT:
It shall be the duty of the superintendent and the village police and all
persons in the employ of the village having police power, to enforce the
provisions of all ordinances, rules and regulations respecting the sewer and
water system and to arrest or cause to be arrested all persons violating the
same. (1985 Code § 7-3A-7)
8-3A-8: PENALTY:
Any person who shall violate, neglect or refuse to comply with, or resist the
enforcement of any of the provisions of this article, where there are no
provisions to the contrary, in addition to the enforcement of the forfeiture,
liability, stipulations and reservations, or for any violation not otherwise
provided for herein, shall, upon conviction, be fined not less than twenty five
dollars ($25.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00). (1985
Code § 7-3A-8; amd. 2016 Code)
ARTICLE B. WATER USE AND SERVICE
SECTION:
8-3B-1: Use Of Public System Required
8-3B-2: Construction Requirements
8-3B-3: Meters
8-3B-3-1: Ownership Of Meters
8-3B-3-2: Turning On Water Supply
8-3B-3-3: Responsibility For Water Registered By Meter
8-3B-3-4: Repair And Replacement Of Meters
8-3B-3-5: Tampering With, Damage To Meters Prohibited
8-3B-3-6: Miscellaneous Meter Provisions
8-3B-4: Water Rates And Charges
8-3B-5: Bills For Service; Procedure For Nonpayment
8-3B-6: Improper Use Of Water
8-3B-7: Prohibited Acts And Conditions
8-3B-8: Use Of Unmetered Water
8-3B-9: Village Right To Shut Off Water
8-3B-10: Penalties
8-3B-1: USE OF PUBLIC SYSTEM REQUIRED:
In all cases where a standard water main is now installed or hereafter may be
installed in any street or alley or other public way in the village, all water
users located on any lot or parcel of real estate fronting or abutting on any
such street or alley or other public way shall make or cause to be made
connection to such standard water main and pay the tapping charges therefor
within six (6) months hereafter or within six (6) months after the installation
of such standard water main if the same is not currently installed, and such
users shall discontinue, within the same period of time, any connection which
they may have had with any temporary water line. (1985 Code § 7-3B-1)
8-3B-2: CONSTRUCTION REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Permit Requirements: Any person or corporation desiring to make any
connection with the water system or use water therefrom shall first make
application to the superintendent upon a form or forms to be furnished by the
department. Said application shall contain an agreement on the part of the
applicant that there will be compliance with all the rules and regulations,
conditions and provisions of any ordinance relating to the water and sewer
system; that all water rates and charges and all fines and penalties assessed,
charged or imposed against said applicant or the property described in said
application will be paid. When the applicant hereunder has complied with all
the provisions of the ordinances of the village, a permit shall then be issued
by the superintendent authorizing the connection to be made and specifying the
size thereof. All plumbing and plumbing work and all excavating, filling and
replacement of pavement shall be done by a plumber authorized by the ordinances
of the village to do such plumbing; provided, however, all such replacement of
pavement shall be done by the village in accordance with the provisions of this
code or other applicable ordinances. The permit shall authorize any such
plumber to do such plumbing and plumbing work as is described in the permit.
   B.   Specifications:
      1.   Method Of Installation:
         a.   Whenever any permit for a connection with the water mains of the
village is issued herein, the superintendent, or an employee of the village so
designated for the work by the superintendent, shall tap the main of said
system where such connection is to be made and shall insert the corporation
cock.
         b.   The connection from the main to the service cock shall be placed
at least five feet (5') below the level of the ground, and type K copper pipe
shall be laid sufficiently waiving so that it shall be at least one foot (1')
longer than if laid in a straight line and shall be placed in such manner as to
prevent rupture or breakage from settling to the ground.
         c.   Every person supplied with water from the village sewer and water
system shall, at his own cost and expense, have installed and kept in repair
all pipes leading from the buffalo or shutoff box to his building, structure or
premises which is supplied with water through such service pipe.
         d.    Each water service pipe shall be connected with the main water
pipe and shall extend horizontally at right angles with the main water pipe to
a point at least eighteen feet (18') from the centerline of the street and
shall be provided with a brass stopcock of not less than one inch (1") in
diameter to be installed with a telescopic shutoff box of the best quality of
cast iron or first grade steel pipe.
2. Materials And Sizes:
a. No connection with any water main of the village shall be less than one inch
(1"), type K copper pipe.
